Corrective actions completed or planned include 1) similar locations were inspected for weld defects, 2) enhanced training of the specific weld type, and 3) planned mockups for future high risk / high value welds. This event had no effect on the public health and safety. The event was reported to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission on June 12, 2018, via Event Notification 53456.

On March 23, 2020, at 10:12 Eastern Daylight Time, Shearon Harris Nuclear Power Plant, Unit 1 (HNP), experienced an automatic reactor trip following actuation of the Reactor Protection System (RPS). The trip occurred during restoration from a planned maintenance activity that impacted the auto-stop turbine (AST) trip function of the digital electro-hydraulic

On February 8 2016 at approximately 0147 hours during a surveillance test, control room indications identified that 3B Emergency Containment Cooler (ECC) fan tripped. Troubleshooting found the control power fuse for the fan's power supply breaker was loose in its fuse holder. Investigation revealed that the fuse holder clips had been widened during work activities associated with the installation of the new breaker during the prior Unit 3 refueling and maintenance outage. The most probable cause of the loose fuse was improper insertion. In addition, the installation procedure did not validate fuse holder gap, fuse alignment, and fuse tightness after its last removal and insertion prior to placing the new breaker in service. Inadequate contact during the surveillance test caused the fan trip. The 3B ECC would not have reliably met its safety function mission time and so was determined to be inoperable for approximately 72 days exceeding the 72 hour Technical Specification allowed outage time. Corrective actions include: 1) The fuse holder clips were adjusted to provide a tight fit. 2) A review determined additional similar breakers will be inspected for fuse tightness. 3) Future installation and preventive maintenance of similar breakers will check for fuse tightness and correct if necessary. Safety significance is considered low based on a risk assessment showing Incremental Conditional Core Damage Probability and Incremental Conditional Large Early Release Probability are below the NRC acceptance criteria for minimal risk impact.

On September 18 2018 with the reactor at 100 percent power at approximately 0525 hours Operators manually tripped the reactor and shut the Main Steam Isolation Valves due to a steam leak on the 6 inch elbow located upstream of the 36C Feedwater Heater. The steam leak was due to a failure of the 6 inch elbow. The cause of the failure was flow accelerated corrosion which lead to pipe wall thinning and subsequent pipe failure. Ultrasonic testing of the elbow showed flow accelerated corrosion thinning in the failed elbow and also in the adjacent upstream elbow. Following the reactor trip, the plant was stabilized in hot standby with decay heat being removed from the steam generators via the Auxiliary Feedwater System and atmospheric steam dumps. This event had no effect on the public health and safety.

On February 10, 2014, Monticello personnel identified that the Emergency Diesel Generators (EDGs) would not energize permanently connected loads until 10.2 or 10.34 seconds for Division I and Division II, respectively, which exceeded the 10-second limitation of Monticello Technical Specification (TS) Surveillance Requirement (SR) 3.8.1.12. As a result, both EDGs were declared inoperable. The apparent cause of this event is that the description of the EDG TS SR was inadvertently changed during the transition from custom TS 4.9.B.3 to improved TS SR 3.8.1.12 due to improper verification and validation practices of the Improved TS preparation team in 2004-2006. The set-points for the applicable relays have been revised. The time delay set-point change provides a setting to support EDG performance meeting the 10-second acceptance criterion of SR 3.8.1.12. Additionally, the surveillance procedure will be revised as necessary to implement correct testing for SR 3.8.1.12.

On September 18, 2013, the plant was in Mode 1 with reactor power at 100 percent. At 1555, an unqualified valve diaphragm was identified to have been installed on Air Operated Valve 2RE9160A, Reactor Coolant Drain Tank to Waste Gas (GW) Compressor Inside Containment Isolation Valve during the 2011 refuel outage. The 2RE9160A valve was immediately declared inoperable based on the unqualified valve diaphragm. The associated containment penetration was isolated per the required actions in Byron Technical Specification (TS) 3.6.3, Condition A. Since the condition existed for longer than allowed by TS 3.6.3 (Containment Isolation Valves), Required Action A.1, i.e., for more than 4 hours, this is a reportable condition. The cause of the event was an incorrect assumption made by the Maintenance Work Planner to use an unqualified valve diaphragm in a qualified application.

On July 8  2024  at 1927  James A. FitzPatrick Nuclear Power Plant (JAF) received annunciators and indication of a half-scram on the "B" side Reactor Protection System (RPS). The cause was determined to be an overvoltage condition that tripped the Electrical Protection Assembly (EPA) for the "B" RPS Motor Generator (MG) Set. This event caused invalid primary containment isolation signals in multiple systems. The investigation into the cause of the event is ongoing. A supplement to this report will be submitted when the investigation is complete.

On May 15, 2014, an unsealed conduit penetration was identified between two fire zones, Division I and Division II of safe shutdown equipment in the Emergency Filtration (EFT) Building, which does not meet the two-hour fire barrier rating of the wall required per the Fire Hazards Analysis. The cause of the unsealed penetration is unknown and is considered a legacy issue as this conduit was routed prior to 1991. The EFT fire protection barrier will be restored to functional status and the penetration will be periodically inspected. The Fire Barrier Wall, Damper, and Floor Inspection procedure will be revised to add use of additional tools (e.g., cameras or boroscope) to perform inspections on portions of fire barriers that are not easily accessed.

On May 19th 2021 during the periodic scheduled performance of Plant Protection System (PPS) functional testing an invalid actuation of the Safety Injection Actuation Signal, Containment Isolation Actuation Signal, and Main Steam Isolation Signal (MSIS) of both trains occurred. This led to a reactor trip and the start of the Diesel Generators and Essential Spray Pond pumps. In addition, Low Steam Generator level signals actuated the Auxiliary Feedwater Actuation Signals which started both essential Auxiliary Feedwater pumps. The Unit 2 reactor tripped because of High Pressurizer Pressure that occurred as a result of a transient initiated by the MSIS actuation and rapid closure of the Main Steam Isolation Valves. This event was initiated by a failure of the Engineered Safety Features Actuation System (ESFAS) test circuit which caused a loss of hold power circuit continuity for critical ESFAS trip paths through the PPS Relay Hold Switch which allowed the trip signals to initiate the applicable plant response. The PPS components involved with the trip were replaced on May 21, 2021, and plant operation was restored. At the time of the trip, PVNGS Unit 1 was operating at 100 percent power and Unit 3 was in a refueling outage. Neither unit was impacted by the event. No previous similar events have been reported by PVNGS.

At 2002 Eastern Standard Time (EST) on January 17, 2018, Watts Bar Nuclear Plant Unit 1 annulus differential pressure went outside its pressure limit. At that time, the Shield Building was declared inoperable requiring entry into Technical Specification 3.6.15 Limiting Condition for Operation (LCO) Conditions A and B. Action was taken by field operators to swap annulus vacuum control dampers due to slow system response to restore annulus differential pressure. At 2024 EST, annulus differential pressure was restored to required limits, the Shield Building was declared operable, and TS 3.6.15 LCO Conditions A and B were exited. This is being reported as an event or condition that could have prevented fulfillment of a safety function. The cause of this transient is a combination of slow damper response and procedural issues. Immediate corrective actions to address this included the completion of damper field tuning. Procedure changes for operation of the annulus vacuum system will be completed and preventative maintenance instructions will be revised to require field tuning on annulus vacuum control dampers. A supplement to this LER will be made with the results of additional cause evaluation and corrective actions for this event.

On November 26 2012, Operator review of a tag-out for a Preventive Maintenance of the Steam Generator (SG) blowdown (SGBD) radiation monitor R-49 determined the tagout would have placed all the SGBD isolation valves (ISVs) in Rad Bypass. Operators could not identify any procedure allowing this action and determined this action was previously reported in LER-2012-004 as an unanalyzed condition and safety system functional failure when an Auxiliary Feedwater pump is out of service. The normal ISV position is open which allows the ISVs to Auto close for heat sink events (Loss of Normal Feedwater Loss of All AC Power to the Station Auxiliaries) in addition to containment Phase A isolation. Analyzed degraded heat sink events assume SGBD isolation occurs and continuous SGBD during these events has not been analyzed. SG inventory would not be maintained if only one motor-driven AFW pump was operable as it may not provide adequate flow with the SGBD ISVs open. A review identified previous tagouts that placed the SGBD ISVs in Rad Bypass with an Auxiliary Feedwater pump or its emergency power supply inoperable. The apparent cause has not been determined. Corrective action was revision of procedure 2-PC-2Y23-49 to delete steps to place in Rad Bypass while performing Radiation Monitor R-49 calibration and installation of a test jumper to disable the blowdown function (as reported in LER- 2012-004). Applicable archived tagouts were locked from further use. UFSAR Section 14.1.9 was revised to state SGBD isolation is assumed starting from event initiation. An apparent cause evaluation will be performed. The event had no significant effect on public health and safety.

On May 3, 2024, during a refueling outage, Hope Creek Generating Station (HCGS) performed Primary Containment Integrated Leak Rate Testing (ILRT) Type A test as required by Technical Specification 4.6.1.2. The as-found test was not completed successfully because the stabilization criteria were not met, and the test was invalidated. The as-left test was completed successfully prior to plant start-up. This licensee event report (LER) supplement provides the results of a Root Cause Evaluation (RCE). The Direct Cause was inadequate bolt seating torque that led to loss of O-ring seal compression. The Root Cause was identified as inadequate procedural guidance for validating and measuring flange to drywell airlock surface gap. This event was reported to the NRC as an eight-hour non-emergency in Event Notification number 57103 on May 3, 2024. Subsequently, LER 2024-001-00 was submitted on July 2, 2024, reporting the event. This LER supplement also identifies additional reporting criterion.

On March 10, 2017, during a Technical Specification surveillance, the as-found operating time of one of four undervoltage timing relays in a Safety related 4.16kV switchgear was greater than the Technical Specification allowable value. The relay was retested without making any changes to the relay timing or the test configuration. The second test resulted in a lower value that was within the Technical Specification allowable value but outside the acceptance criteria of the procedure. A third test (and subsequent follow-up testing) resulted in values that met Technical Specification limits. The associated channel was declared Operable. On March 14, 2017, an engineer reviewed the surveillance results and questioned the reliability of the relay based on its behavior. The Control Room was contacted and the relay was replaced. Based on the engineer's analysis, the Shift Manager determined that the relay should not have been declared Operable on March 10. The Technical Specification Action Statement required the inoperable channel to be placed in the tripped condition within 72 hours. This Action was not met and is reportable as a condition prohibited by Technical Specifications. The event was of very low risk significance and no radioactive release occurred; therefore, there was no adverse effect on the health and safety of the public.

On June 12, 2014, while operating at 100 percent power in Mode 1, Harris plant personnel determined that inadequate cable protection existed in control cables for the Turbine Emergency Oil Pump. The cables had no electrical protection devices (fuses) other than the circuit breaker. The control cables are routed through several fire areas, including the main control room, and under postulated conditions, could have created a common enclosure fire hazard situation. Compensatory measures (hourly fire watches) were implemented for affected areas of the plant to ensure continued public safety until electrical protection devices were installed. The apparent cause was the historical installation of an unfused section of cable in the control circuit of the Turbine Emergency Oil Pump.

At approximately 2333 on July 26, 2013, electrical faults caused damage to the isophase bus to the unit auxiliary transformer and main generator neutral connection box. Protective relaying initiated a generator trip to isolate the faulted area and to trip the main turbine. A reactor trip from 100% power resulted from the turbine trip. A small cable insulation and oil collection pan fire initiated from the main generator neutral connection box fault and created smoke throughout the Turbine Building. An Unusual Event was declared as a result of the fire and resulting smoke. The fire was extinguished within 30 minutes and smoke was removed from the building using installed equipment. The electrical faults were the result of a damper blade that was loose within the isophase bus ductwork, creating arcing between the bus, damper blade, and duct. The loose damper blade is attributed to damper failure based on the determination that the operational isophase bus duct airflow rate exceeded the design flow rate for the backdraft dampers. Design and installation errors were made at the main generator neutral connection box during plant construction. Redesigned backdraft dampers were installed, and grating was added to prevent debris from entering the isophase bus ducts. Modifications were also made to the generator neutral connection box.

On November 29, 2021, at 1458 Central Standard Time (CST), while operating in Mode 1 at 100% power, Arkansas Nuclear One, Unit 1 (ANO-1) automatically tripped due to high Reactor Coolant System pressure following a Main Feedwater System transient. All control rods fully inserted and all systems responded as designed. The plant was stabilized in Mode 3 (Hot Standby). The cause of the Main Feedwater System transient was the failure of the 'A' MFP High Pressure (HP) governor to respond to lowering 'A' MFP speed. The initiating event was a failure of the 'A' MFP LP governor servo drive and actuator. When the LP governor servo drive failed, the HP governor did not respond to restore 'A' MFP speed. Proper program values had not been input in the HP governor controller during previous maintenance in 2015. The HP governor failure to respond resulted in underfeeding the 'A' Steam Generator and an automatic reactor trip due to high Reactor Coolant System pressure.

At 1258 CDT on August 3 2022 with Joseph M. Farley Nuclear Plant (FNP) Unit 1 in Mode 1 at 100 percent power the reactor automatically tripped following a generator trip and subsequent turbine trip signal. A floor tile was dropped in the high voltage switch house resulting in a relay actuation that electrically isolated Bus 1 in the 230kV switchyard. The "B" train emergency safeguards (ES) bus lost power along with 1B, 1C, and 1E non safety related 4160V busses. The 1A 4160V non safety bus did not fast bus transfer to its alternate power supply, which along with isolation of the 230kV Bus 1, resulted in all Reactor Coolant Pumps being deenergized. Residual heat was removed by natural circulation via the atmospheric relief valves. The 1B emergency diesel automatically actuated due to the loss of power to the "B" train ES bus. In addition, the Auxiliary Feedwater System (AFW) automatically started as expected in response to the reactor trip. Corrective actions include calibrating the associated relays following revision to calculations and relay sheets. Additionally, the design calculation change process will be revised to ensure plant impacts are incorporated into plant procedures. FNP Unit 2 was not affected during this event.

Fort Calhoun Station (FCS) operating procedures allow filling and sluicing multiple safety injection tanks (SITs) while at power rendering the SITs inoperable during the evolution. The use of this procedure allowed multiple safety injection tanks to be concurrently filled while FCS was at power. FCS Technical Specifications (TS) and accident analysis do not allow more than one SIT to be inoperable. This condition was identified on March 19, 2012, while the unit was in Mode 5 by the NRC during initial license examination preparation. The cause of this condition was the failure to recognize that the passive design of the SITs cannot credit the use of active components for operability. The event was entered into the Corrective Action Program and the following corrective actions were taken. Operating Procedure OI-SI-1, the Technical Specification basis, and the Updated Safety Analysis Report have been revised to clearly state the SITs operability requirements.

The reactor building DP became greater than -0.25" H20 which rendered secondary containment inoperable due to not meeting SR 3.6.4.1.1. Due to troubleshooting efforts on the reactor building DP loop, the possibility existed that building DP would be affected as a part of the troubleshooting maintenance WO. Required actions of the TS were implemented, adjustments were made to the VR exhaust flow and reactor building DP was brought back into the green band, -0.5" H20. A system walkdown validated the DP excursion was due to this planned evolution.

During the OPEX review of Browns Ferry Fire Protection ENS 47374, "DEFICIENCY IDENTIFIED IN TRANSITION TO PERFORMANCE BASED STANDARD FOR FIRE PROTECTION", a similar condition was identified at Clinton Power Station. Specifically, at Browns Ferry, the wiring design for the station battery ammeter contains a "shunt" in the current flow off the battery. Bolted on the shunt bar are two leads to a current meter in the main control room. The tiny difference in voltage between the two taps on the shunt is enough to deflect the current gauge in the MCR when current flows from the battery thru the shunt. At Brown's Ferry, the ammeter wiring attached to the shunt does not have fuses. If these ammeter wires were grounded, shorted together, or open-circuited, there is no real affect to the battery. However, if one of these ammeter wires shorts to ground, at the same time another DC wire from the opposite polarity on the same battery also shorts to ground, a ground loop thru the unfused ammeter cable could occur. With enough current going thru the cable, the potential exists that a secondary fire in the raceway system could occur wherever the cable is routed. Review of the CPS design identified a similar condition, as no protective devices (fuses) are installed off of the shunts to the Main Control Room ammeters. The DC distribution system is a floating system with no established ground other than the high resistance ground provided through the ground detector. It is designed in this manner to allow the system to withstand one hard ground (zero resistance) with no adverse affect on the operation of any equipment fed from the DC system. If a second ground with low enough resistance is placed on the DC system, the operation of the grounded equipment could be adversely affected. The two ground paths could short around components to prevent them from operating or provide a current path to spuriously operate a piece of equipment. In the case of the Browns Ferry ENS described above, if one ammeter wire shorts to ground (which will be annunciated by the ground detection system), and a second ground develops on the opposite polarity of the same battery, a ground loop thru the unfused ammeter cable could occur. With enough current going thru the cable, the potential exists that a secondary fire in the raceway system could occur wherever the cable is routed. Schematic Diagrams/Drawings E02-1DC99-001 (1A), E02-1DC99-002 (1B), E02-1HP99-209 (1C), and E02-1DC99-003 (1D) were reviewed and confirmed this design configuration. In the Clinton Power Station Updated Final Safety Analysis Report (UFSAR), Appendix F, Safe Shutdown Analysis, Section 1.5, Associated Circuits, describes that: The NRC, in Generic Letter 81-12, defines associated circuits of concern as those cables that have a physical separation less than that required by Section III.G.2 of Appendix R and have one of the following: - A common enclosure with safe shutdown cables that are not electrically protected by circuit breakers, fuses, or similar devices, or will allow propagation of the fire into the common enclosure. Within the same section, the Clinton identification of associated circuits of concern is as follows: - Cables that have a common enclosure with safe shutdown cables and are not electrically protected by circuit breakers or fuses and are not provided with fire stops where they penetrate fire barriers are considered to be safe shutdown cables; however, this condition was not found to exist at Clinton. In summary, the Clinton UFSAR concluded that associated non-safe shutdown cables that are not electrically protected and share a common enclosure with safe shutdown cables do not exist at Clinton. The above scenario would not be in agreement with this statement. As such, this scenario is a violation of UFSAR Appendix F, Section 1.5 statements/commitments for circuit protection. Engineering reviewed the safety design basis for the Station Battery System and found that the design of this system meets all general design criteria and the requirements of IEEE 484 and IEEE 946. Illustrations in IEEE 946 show no fuses installed for a typical ammeter circuit from the battery shunts. Also, the S&L design standard for DC Aux Power Systems (ESC-291) does not specify fusing for the ammeter shunt circuit and references IEEE-946. Therefore, this condition affects CPS compliance to Appendix R and GL 81-12 but does not affect any TS and USAR described limits or functions of the DC auxiliary power system.
The 125VDC ground was previously documented under IR 1349238. Troubleshooting found that the U1 DG Governor Oil Booster pump had 1ohm to ground.

During performance of QCOS 0201-08, REACTOR VESSEL CLASS 1 AND ASSOCIATED CLASS 2 SYSTEM LEAK TEST, under WO 1359196, Programs Engineer assigned to the 3rd and 4th floor of the Drywell identified water coming from the penetration N11B. Insulation was removed for better access. The water was coming from the annulus between the nozzle and the vessel wall. This nozzle is welded on the inside of the vessel, so the actual attachment weld could not be seen. The water was leaving the penetration at approximately 60 dpm. Some corrosion (no wastage) was observed on the Reactor Pressure Vessel directly above the nozzle. No leakage was found at the corresponding N11A nozzle.
wo 1334414-01 (01/21/2012) removed the heads on the B control HX. Ir 01389491 found a leak on the west head on 07/17/2012. This meets the criteria for possible rework in MA-AA-716-017

The Shift Manager reviewed video of camera inspections conducted inside the "A" D-ring. It was determined that a non-insolable RCS leak was identified at the Pressurizer lower heater bundle. TS 3.1.6.4 is applicable, "if any reactor coolant leakage exists through a nonisolable fault in an RCS strength boundary such as the reactor vessel, piping, valve body, etc., except the steam generator tubes, the reactor shall be shutdown, and a cooldown to the cold shutdown condition shall be initiated within 24 hours of detection.

Received 2B DG Engine Trouble alarm. The Rounds EO reported that while blowing down the 2B DG Starting air receiver she received alarm and the starting air compressor for the A Starting air system started. The EO called again to report that air pressure was continuing to slowly drop and the lowest pressure received was 150 psig. Shortly after this the compressor restored pressure above 200 PSIG.

ERAT and ERAT SVC Tripped: 22:04- Loss of the ERAT. Fire Protection Deluge activated and A & B Fire Pumps Started. 4160 Bus 1A1 was being powered from the ERAT and transferred to the RAT. 22:05- Entered EOP-8 due to Secondary Containment D/P. VF Tripped. 22:16- Notified Rich and Bob at Ameren Dispatch that the ERAT has tripped. 22:18- Started VG 'A'. Secondary Containment restored. 22:31- Received report from Area Operator no signs of fire, damage at ERAT. 22:32- 9082.01 Completed. During momentary loss of power to 4160V 1A1 bus, FC pump A tripped, the fission product monitor isolated, VF isolation dampers lost power and closed. Following Annunciators received for the ERAT trip: 5010-1A: AUTO TRIP SWITCHER 5010-4E: LOCKOUT TRIP EMER RES AUX TRANSF PROT SYS S 5010-5F: SUDDEN PRESS EMERG RES AUX TRANSFORMER 5010-6F: TROUBLE EMERG RES AUX TRANSFORMER 5011-5G: LOCKOUT TRIP BUS 1ET4 PROT SYS S 5011-8E: ERAT SVC TRIP 5011-8F: ERAT SVC TROUBLE

An employee was the non-contaminated runner for WO 1416167. The employee was asked to retrieve equipment from the Reactor Building 3rd Floor Weld Shop. While returning to the job site, the employee passed through the U2 RB to TB interlock on the 595' level. Employee noted the interlock door light was extinguished and opened the interlock door. Upon opening of the interlock door, employee noted the door to the U2 HRSS Building had swung fully open. At that point the employee latched continued through the interlock. Employee dropped off the tools to the personnel inside of the High Rad Area and immediately contacted the Control Room.

PERFORMED SO 40D.7.B TO PLACE MCR EMERGENCY VENTILATION IN SERVICE IN PREPARATION FOR THE E-42 LOOP TEST AND 0AV030 FAILED TO AUTO START. 0BV030 AUTO STARTED DUE TO BEING IN "AUTO-STBY". 0AV030 CONTROL SWITCH WAS VERIFIED TO BE IN "AUTO" PRIOR TO PERFORMING THE PROCEDURE.

During the performance of shifting Main Control Room Ventilation from the A to B train the B Chiller breaker mechanism/charging motor was continuously and repeatingly cycling.resulting in the failure of the breaker. During the shifting of VC, the NLO called the MCR to inform us of a breaker giving off a cycling noise, NLO reported that the VC B chiller breaker was the source of the noise and was directed to shutdown the VC B Chiller. Soon after the MCR received NSPS trouble and a Div 2 DC Ground. VC B was completely shutdown by the MCR RO. NLO reported smoke coming from VC B chiller breaker cubicle. The WEC SRO, SM, and extra RO (incident commander) left the MCR to investigate to VC B breaker problem. Soon after arriving at 480V Unit Sub B, 0AP06E, it was apparent that the VC B chiller breaker required to be immediately deenergized due excessive smoke but no flame. After discusing actions that were needed to be performed to terminate the breaker failure, the field personnel deenergize 0AP06E by depressing that Unit Sub remote trip pushbutton. The VC B Chiller breaker was then racked out. After evaluating plant conditions and Unit Sub conditions the Unit Sub was then reenergized to support plant systems restoration. All associated EOPs and Off-Normals where entered and performed. The Fire Brigade was activated and responded by removing the VC B Chiller breaker from the Unit Sub cubicle and spraying down the breaker with Halon and Water, and removing smoke from the area. The following is the MCR log entry: 19:56 - EO reports that VC B Chiller Breaker Cycling open and closed. Several indications on the horizontal panel on 5052 were cycling as indicated by lights going on and off. 19:57 - 5002-5N NSPS in trouble (loss of Synch). 20:02 - Smoke reported in Unit Sub B Stationed Andy Siegmund as IA. 20:03 - 5003--5M in with local trip of 480V Unit Sub B after the trip the 1IA006 and 1IA007 went closed. Due to VC B Breaker cycling on 480V Unit Sub B declared VC B Inop and Unavailable entered LCO Actions. The following equipment lost power during while the Unit Sub B was deenergized: Div 2 Inverter Room Cooler. Div 4 Inverter Room Cooler. 20:05- Field re-energizes Unit Sub B, Plant Risk was Yellow during the 2 minutes that Unit Sub B was de-energized. Called away Fire Brigade. 20:07 - Bus voltages on Unit Sub B were verified within bands and with the breaker for the VC B Chiller removed. 20:08 - Started A Fire Pump per CPS 1893.04 20:08 - Entered EOP-8 due to Secondary Ctmt pressure above O psid. 20:09 - Re-opened 1IA006/7 20:11 - Started VG A to restore Secondary Ctmt d/p per CPS 3319.01 Step 8.2.1 20:13 - Secondary Ctmt d/p restored exit LCO 3.6.4.1 Action A.1 20:33 - Completed Shutdown of VR/VQ per CPS 3408.01 Step 8. 1.3 20:37 - Performed step 8.1.1.1.3 of CPS 3408.01 (per procedure enter this time in the logs) 20:38 - Restarted VR/ VQ per CPS 3408.01 20:46 - Started VC A Ventilation train. 21:15 - Placed VF in Shut down Lineup and reset VF Isolation per CPS 3404.01 Section 8.3 21:25 - Reopened 1SA030 Service air Ctmt Isolation. 22:13 - Received ECCS Floor Drain Hi Leak Rate alarm 5064-7C 22:15 - Received call from Security that there was water on the floor in The RHR C room and that there was an active leak. Evaluated entering The Flooding Off Normal. 22:18 - C Area operator reports that the SX relief valve off of the RHR C room cooler is lifting and overflowing the funnel. 22:22 - Secured SX Pump B, SX relief valve reseated, during the time that the SX Pump B HS was in PTL Div 2 SX is INOPERABLE 22:45 - Momentarily placed Div 1 and Div 2 Cnmt HVAC Isol Vlv Rad Intlk Bypass switches in TOTAL BYPASS one switch at a time .. 1RIX-PR001A/C (B/D), 1RIX-PR042A/C (B/D), 1RIX-PR006A/C (B/D) were momentarily bypassed and inoperable. 22:48 - Shutdown VG A and restarted VF 22:53 - Placed 0RIX-PR008 in Standby per CPS 3315.03 Section 8.14 23:19 - ECCS Floor Drain Hi Leak Rate alarm 5064-7C has re-set.

During performance of 9431.17, (AVERAGE POWER RANGE MONITOR FLOW BIASED/NEUTRON FLUX RESPONSE TIME TEST) a test cable connector contacted fuse block staple jumper in back of 1H13-P672, causing transfer of Division 4 NSPS bus to reserve feed. Technicians had already disconnected the field connectors from the LPRMs (step 8.1.3) and had run the test cables from the front of P674 through to the rear of panel. Technicians were connecting test box cable connectors to LPRM jacks (step 8.1.4) when one connector fell from technician's hand, striking metal staple jumper on fuse block below. This fuse block was identified during the initial two-minute drill (prior to starting work) and protective plastic was placed over the fuses to mitigate hazards, however it did not cover the very end of the staple jumper surface on the near end of the fuse block. Technicians had walked around to front of panel to check indications, when Operations notified them of plant condition. All work was immediately stopped and IMD Supervision was notified. Fuses were visually inspected to find all of the blown fuse indicators were NOT indicating blown fuse.

Notified that both air lock doors on U1 RB 710' elevation between Chemistry Hot Lab and the RB were momentarily open at the same time. Momentarily entered and exited TS 3.6.4.1. At the time of the occurrence, no movement of irradiated fuel, core alts, or OPDRV's were in progress. Secondary Containment D/P remained in the green band before, during, and after the occurrence. Doors are closed and secure and are being administratively controlled.
At 0756 on 3/7/2013 received reactor scram due to generator trip. Initiated investigation as to cause of trip.

During Q1R22 RPV Pressure Leak Test at the end of the outage, a 20 dpm leak was identified in the Class 2 portion of the RPV Head Vent Line 1-0215-2"-B. The leak is located at the 90 degree elbow at the junction of the vertical section of pipe from above the insulation package and the horizontal section of pipe going to the last 90 degree elbow before the pipe exists through the DW Bulkhead. The leakage is coming thru-wall in the socket weld of the 90 degree elbow to the horizontal section of the pipe.

At approximately 1325 on 4/18/2013, while attempting to raise Unit 1 Reactor level with LPCS system, LPCS Injection Valve 1E21-F005 failed to open as required when the associated control switch was held in the "OPEN" position. The "OPEN" position light bulb was replaced (4 times) and control switch was held in the "OPEN" position sufficiently long enough to cause the valve to open. There were no changes in indicated pump flow and "CLOSED" position indication light did not flicker, indicating that the valve did not attempt to move. The "LPCS INJ VLV LO RX PRESS PERMISSIVE" alarm was activated. An Equipment Operator was dispatched to 1H13-P629 panel to check status of low pressure injection permissive relays K8 and K20. The Equipment Operator reported both relays energized with all contact "fingers" properly aligned and making physical contact. Refer to 1E-1-4221AB, 1E-1-4221AD and 1E-1-4221AE.

Operations personnel were attempting to dewater the Main Condenser East water box per LOP-CW-10, in conjunction with placement of C/O 64222. This was being done to support plugging of a suspected tube leak. The East water box had been isolated by electrically closing the 2CW007A and 2CW007C valves earlier in the day. An Operations supervisor and 2 EO's were attempting to torque the 2CW007A East water box valve into its seat to improve the isolation, using a torque sheet provided by Programs Engineering. The operators were also using match marks on the MOV actuator as a gage to determine if the valve was optimally in the seat. While torquing the 2CW007A valve closed, the EO's felt the wrench pop as the valve position indicator neared the closed match mark, and then noted the pointer move slightly past the mark. The operators stopped all valve work at that point. The supervisor was going to the East water box upper manway to check isolation status when he noted water starting to come out of the manway from apparent leakage past the 2CW007A valve. The Main Control Room and the OCC were immediately notified and asked for assistance. The supervisor was able to access the East water box upper manway and get it closed. He then proceeded to the East outlet water box and close the manway at that end of the condenser. Water from the manway leakage accumulated on the condenser pit floor to a high enough depth to trip the running U2 CW pumps. The Control Room mnaually scrammed U2 when the CW pumps tripped.

During performance on ST-2-092-323-2 relay 127Z-11702 reset value was out of acceptalbe value. During the recalibration the relay the 45 time limit established in the test was approaching and operations racked out the 201 breaker on the D23 bus. The relay was recalibrated within acceptable limits and the test was reperfomed and was completed satisfactory. Operations was notified of satisfactory completion of the test.

During breaker maintenance (LES-GM-103) on the 1C RHR pump it was noticed that the 1A DG cooling water pump had auto started. An investigation into the auto start is being conducted at this time. It appears that this issue may be related to the MOC/TOC switch in the 1C RHR BKR cubicle.

The Division 3 Diesel Ventilation System Supply Air Damper 1VD01YC did not open as expected during Division 3 VD fan start. System Managers and CMO personnel observed the supply damper and associated hydramotor, 1TZD003A, during the fan start. The hydramotor moved approximately one inch in the open direction but did not move the damper. After a few minutes of operation the damper blades did open (approximately 10 to 20% open). When the fan was secured the hydramotor closed the damper with a smooth motion. The damper control is designed to modulate the damper to maintain supply air temperature at a setpoint of 70 degrees. The damper should open on fan start if supply air temperature is greater than 70 degrees. The hydramotor receives a 4 to 20 milliamp signal from temperature controller 1TICVD003. At the time of fan start, Fan Room temperature was 81 degrees at the supply air sensor. The 1TICVD003 was set to 70 degrees and was reading 84 degrees. Therefore the damper should have opened on fan start. Additionally, CMO personnel observed that normally the damper fully opens on fan start and then modulates as needed. The hydramotor / damper assembly is fail closed. In the judgment of the personnel observing the equipment, the three possible causes are: The hydramotor is not exerting the appropriate force to move the damper, the hydramotor is not receiving the correct signal from the controller, or the linkage is bound. The lowest linkage bar does appear to rub the hydramotor gearbox coupling when fully shut and may be adding resistance to the opening motion.

Received unit 2 Reactor enclosure low d/p alarm. When alarm was received, d/p was -.18" and already recovering. d/p immediately stabilized to a normal -.33". Suspect two doors of the same airlock may have been opened simultaneously. HVAC was walked down and all equipment is operating sat. This is now reportable

The FP FASA team identified a potential noncompliance with the Safe Shutdown Analysis for a fire outside the DG rooms (fire zone CB-1e, CB-1f, CB-2 and CB-4). The CO2 panels for each DG train are all located in the same area outside the DG engine bay rooms (737 Control) and a fire in this area could cause fire damage to all three CO2 panels and/or wiring such that a trip (short) could be initiated to all three VD fans. Loss of the VD fans (1VD01CA, B and C) results in loss of cooling in the DG rooms and ultimately loss of the diesels. The availability of offsite power to the 4kv switchgear has not been analyzed for its availability in this fire area. The Fire Safe Shutdown Analysis (IP-M-0532) resolution codes 21 and 22 for this scenario directs operators to take manual control of the fans from the main control room and bypass the CO2 trip. This same language is also present in USAR Appendix F section 3.3.1.5 and IP-M-0471 Attachment 9. However, review of the associate ventilation fan and CO2 control schematics (E02-1VD99 sheets 1, 2, 3, 7, 8 and E02-1CO99 sheets 6, 7, 8) indicate that once the CO2 system actuates the VD fan is tripped (if running) and blocked from restarting with the trip/block signals remaining in place until manually reset at the local CO2 control panels (1CO05JA, B and C). Consequently, the MCR control switch cannot bypass the CO2 trip signal rendering all three DG units unavailable. Based on the FASA review, this issue appears to be a historical/legacy issue. Some variation does exist within each divisional VD fan control logic as follows: - 1VD01CA: Division 1 Diesel Generator 1A room vent fan: The standing CO2 trip signal can be bypassed through the remote shutdown panel allowing restart of the cooling fan. However, there is currently no procedural guidance to perform this action. - 1VD01CB: Division 2 Diesel Generator 1B room vent fan: The standing CO2 trip signal has no external bypass mechanism. In order to restart the Division 2 fan, the CO2 standing trip must be reset at the local panel (1CO05JB) or the trip removed via lifted lead in order to restore fan operation. - 1VD01CC: Division 3 Diesel Generator 1C room vent fan: The standing CO2 trip signal can be bypassed with the MCR fan start control switch. However, the switch is a spring return to auto that will result in the fan stopping if released. Continuous fan operation would require a dedicated operator or some other mechanism to maintain the switch in the close position. - 1H13-P839 fuse F3 (H/F1) provides power to the CO2 trip initiation logic relays that cause loss of all 3 divisional VD fans. Removal of the fuse will clear the trip/block interlocks allowing manual restart of the VD fans from the MCR. However, there is currently no procedural guidance to perform this action. (ref drawings E02-1VD99 sheet 7 and E02-1LV99 sheet 6) The FASA also identified incorrect and insufficient guidance for VD fan restoration in the event of fire-induced circuit damage involving the DG CO2 protection system. CPS procedure 1893.04 (Appendix C steps 3.9 and 3.10) states to take manual control of the fans from the MCR per CPS procedure 3403.01. Review of 3403.01 section 8.8 (CO2 Initiation) simply states that "when the CO2 initiation signal clears. start VD per section 8.1". While it is true that VD can be started after the CO2 initiation signal is cleared, there is no guidance as to how this can be performed or accomplished.

During startup of Reactor from 1M30, the unit experienced an elevation of off gas line flow starting at 0700. Vacuum started to degrade at approx 1030. During that span of time, Operators completed 625.4.002 section 18 for the Speed Governor Operability satisfactory and had started 625. 4.001 for Turbine Overspeed. The test was paused due AVR response in step 6.6.5. Operations entered ABN 14 Loss of Condenser Vacuum at 1050. Once ABN 14 was entered, additional SJAE sets were placed in service until all 6 jet sets were in service. Power was lowered with Recirc Flow than Inseting control rods. At 1110, the turbine was manually tripped and ABN 10 was entered. At 1130, manual scram was initiated and ABN 1 was entered.

An employee entered the secondary containment interlock via door 225 (710 Chem lab to U-1 RB) and while in the airlock while door 225 was closing, another employee opened the other secondary containment interlock door thereby having two doors open. Both doors in the interlock were open for approximately 10 seconds.

UNEXPECTED ALARM 902-4 E-19, RX/TURB 517 INTLK DOORS INOP/BYP. Actions Taken: GCA reported that the RB side of the door was opened and the TB side came open several inches and then re-closed. AT 08:42 Entered and Exited T.S. 3.6.4.1 A.1 NLO was contacted to investigate. The doors had alarmed and reset in less than 1 second. Both interlock doors were verified operating normally and one door was closed at all times the NLO was in attendance. GCA now in attendance operating the doors for employees to traverse the area.

The volumetric examination of the RC-P-1B 2 inch diameter drain line elbow to pipe weld was performed under work order C2029343 activity 3. Reference drawing: 1D-ISI-RC-002 A UT indication was recorded on the pipe side at Top Dead Center of the weld, and IR 1580462 was generated. Subsequent weld prep was performed to remove the weld crown and additional UT characterization was then done. Review of pre-service Radiographs from a 1995 pipe repair showed significant weld geometry on the pipe inside diameter. Past UT data (2001 and 2009) recorded geometry indications in the same area as the current indication. Encoded phased array was utilized on the drain line for confirmation of the indication. The phased area examination showed the indication was not geometric in appearance and the indication was subsequently declared a flaw. The flaw is 50% through wall and extends circumferentially fro 0.8 inches. The flaw is ID connected initiating on the pipe side of the weld and extends into the weld.

During the performance of DOS 7000-26 LLRT of the 2-220-62B the leak rate was above the acceptance criteria of 45.0 scfh. The leak rate was unmeasurable from the test box as the leak rate was too high for the system to pressurize. Air was observed blowing from the test vent valves.
Received 2PM06J-A109, AEER HVAC Pnl 0PA10J trouble alarm.

During the Reactor Vessel System Leakage Test (Hydro), A leak was identified on the 2-0203-3C ERV. The leak is located at the ERV main body to the pilot valve connecting line joint. The leak is approximately 1 drop per second. This is a code boundary leak.

Shift Manager was notified at 1400 that the leakage identified on ERV 2-0203-3C (IR 1590050) during the RPV pressure test was code boundary leakage from an ERV that was not replaced during D2R23. This ERV did have its pilot valve replaced during D2R23. This boundary leakage meets the reportability requirements of SAF 1.4, Degraded or Unanalyzed Condition, and is reportable within 8 hours; The licensee shall notify the NRC Operations Center the leakage identified via the ENS as soon as practical and in all cases within eight hours of the occurrence of any event or condition (that occurred within 3 years of the date of discovery) that results in the condition of the nuclear power plant, including its principal safety barriers, being seriously degraded; or the nuclear power plant being in an Notified at this time that unanalyzed condition that significantly degrades plant safety.

On 11/28/13, at 0258 the Unit 2 902-4 F-19, the X-Area interlock door alarmed. Operations sent an equipment operator into the field to investigate, he found a Radiation Protection Technician and laborers in the area removing lead blankets from the room. He notified the RPT that the control room received an alarm for secondary containment, the RPT told the laborers to close the doors that they had opened. The initial investigation found that a Radiation Protection Technician (RPT) had opened both interlock doors at the U2 X-Area while he and laborers were removing lead blankets from the room. Secondary containment had been reestablished the night before, so in opening both doors at the same time, secondary containment was breached.
During DOS 2300-07 FAST START testing of U2 HPCI the turbine stop valve failed to fully open when initiation signal was given.

A scheduled load reduction for quarterly surveillances and control rod sequence exchange was in progress on LAS Unit 2. The CMSS (3D Monicore) "case" after completion of the first set of three control rod sequence exchanges showed that all APRM readings met the TS SR to verify calculated CTP and APRM readings agree within 2%. After the second set of three control rod sequence exchanges, thermal limits and APRMs were again evaluated by the Shift. It was discovered that all 3 A RPS Average Power Range Monitors (APRMs) exceeded their TS SR for 2% difference between calculated CTP and APRM readings in the non-conservative direction (difference of 2.9, 3.1, and 2.5% respectively). The TS allows a 2 hour delay in entering the Conditions and Required actions for APRM channel inoperability for this situation (i.e. no RA timeclocks were entered). A confirmatory "case" was performed that validated that the subject SR was not met. TS requires at least 2 operable APRM channels per trip system (there are 2 RPS trip systems, A and B). At least 1 of 2 TS required APRM channels are required to maintain the Safety Function (i.e. SCRAM). Prompt action was taken to restore the APRM indications to within limits (this action took approximately 22 minutes to complete) and the subject APRMs were declared operable, restoring the A RPS Safety Function.

The MCR received multiple alarms due to a trip of 4160V 1A1 breaker 1AP07EJ, 480V XFMR 1A and A1 breaker. Area operators were dispatched to investigate trip of breaker. Many Division 1 components lost power (powered from unit subs 1A and A1). Noted containment IA valves had lost power and were closed. Commenced monitoring for scram pilot air header pressure low alarm and potential for control rods to drift due to loss of air. The MCR received scram pilot air header pressure low alarm, 5003-3L. The MCR placed the Reactor Mode Switch in Shutdown.

17:58 -- Placed the mode switch in shutdown due to approaching Reactor Water Level 8 while bringing on TDRFP A in automatic mode; stationed the Incident Assessor. 17:58 -- Entered EOP 1 on Reactor Water Level 3. 17:59 -- Manually tripped turbine generator. GCB 4506 and 4510 tripped as expected. 18:00 -- Reactor water level band Level 3 to Level 8 per 4411.03. Reactor pressure band 800-1065 psig per 4411.09 18:02 -- Minimized cool down loads per 4100.01 Scram off-normal 18:09 -- Constellation Power team has been notified of Clinton Power Station's shutdown. Switching order to re-establish the ring bus obtained from Ameren Dispatch. 18:13 -- Closed inboard Main Steam Isolation valves to maintain cool down rate within limits. 18:15 -- Opened main steam drain valves for pressure control. 18:16 -- Started "A" condenser vacuum pump 0CA01PA to maintain condenser vacuum. 18:26 -- Reactor water level out of band high due to rising reactor water level. 1FW004 was shut, RT letdown to condenser previously established and RD is injecting. 18:29 -- 1B21F065A is shut. 18:31 -- 1B21F065B is shut. 18:33 -- Locally shut 1C11-F034 per 3304.01, section 8.3.9.1.1 to stop rising reactor water level trend. 18:55 -- Division 1 and Division 2 leak detection switches in BYPASS. ITS actions tracked by a separate log entry. 19:03 -- Opened 1B21F065A for 5 seconds. 19:09 -- Opened 1FW024 to feed with CD/CB pumps through 1FW004 in automatic. 20:00 -- Reactor water level band 30-39 inches narrow range to support resetting reactor scram signal.

19:56 - Main Control Room received Annunciators 5042-4D and 5042-5D. Discovered the Supply Fan1VF03CA was tripped and Exhaust Fan 1VF04CA was running with fuel building d/p reading +.5 in/water and Secondary Containment d/p reading 0 in/water. Entered EOP-8. After several seconds the Exhaust Fan 1VF04CA tripped at which time Exhaust Fan 1VF04CB started and ran for several seconds before tripping. Secondary Containment is Inoperable and Unavailable for Maintenance Rule VG-05 due to secondary containment differential pressure greater than -0.25 inches of water. Entered the following LCO Action: - LCO 3.6.4.1 Action A.1 - Restore secondary containment to an operable status in 4 hours. 19:58 - Main Control Room team noticed Inbd Exh Isol Damper 1VF07Y going from intermediate to open. MCR team trended computer point VF-BC804 and at time 19:56 1VF07Y indicated closed and at time 19:58 indicated Not closed. 19:59 - Area operator reports to panel informs MCR all fans are tripped or not running. 20:03 - Fuel Building ventilation restored, Fuel Building d/p and Secondary Containment d/p restored to normal values. Exited LCO 3.6.4.1 Action A.1. 20:13 - Exited EOP-8 The trip of VF occurred while starting up Control Room ventilation train 'B' specifically when starting Control Room Supply Fan 0VC03CB.
Door 507 door does not close and latch properly. Door 507 is located on Unit 2 710 elevation and is one of the two doors in the air lock between the Unit2 DG Corridor to the Unit 2 Reactor Building.

U1 received an unexpected Unit 1 Fuel Pool channel "B" HI alarm. Rad monitor on the 901-10 panel was indicating approximately 50 mr/hr. RP reports that local radiation readings on the refuel floor near the 1B Refuel floor radiation monitor are normal at .2 mr/hr.

With reactor power at 85% steady state at about 19:00 the MCR team noticed OG flow lowering and condenser vacuum lowering and condensate temperature rising. Entered the Loss of Vacuum off-normal and commenced an emergency power reduction when vacuum lowered to 27.4 "hg. While reducing power the MCR team dispatched operators to check the possible causes listed in the off-normal including filling the B SJAE intercondenser loop seal and to start swapping to SJAE A. When vacuum degraded to 24" hg and lowering the CRS directed a rapid plant shutdown as directed in the off-normal. Power was about 46% when the rapid plant shutdown was commenced.

Main Control Received Alarm 902-4 E-21, U2/3 DIESEL GEN INTLK DOORS INOP/BYP. Alarm was received at 01:51:17 and cleared at 01:51:22. An EO notified the MCR that both the 2/3 EDG side and Reactor Building side interlock doors were open at the same time. The EO reports he was in the Rx Bldg heading towards the 2/3 EDG Interlock. When he depressed the button to open the Rx Bldg side interlock door, the Rx Bldg side interlock door started to open. At the same time, maintenance personnel pushed the 2/3 EDG diesel side interlock opening button and the door started opening causing both interlock doors to be open at the same time. The EO immediately closed the 2/3 Rx Bldg side Interlock door. The lights that indicate a door is open were not lit when the open buttons were pushed. Suspect possible failure of the interlocking mechanism on the 2/3 EDG door that prevents both doors from opening at the same time.

Rounds Operator identified excessive D/P across Division 3 Switchgear Room door. The Field Supervisor was contacted and it was determined that either the temperature controller or a damper had failed. Supply fan D/P on1PDI-VD14 was upscale and switchgear room door D/P was increasing. Balancing damper 1VD18Y was also full closed. With concurrence from the control room and shift manager 1VD18Y acuator was disconnected and the damper locked open.

During VT-2 Pressure Testing under WO 01593048-01 a thru wall leak was identified on CRD HCU 18-27 scram inlet isolation valve 2-0305-101. The leak was approximately 2 drips per minute (dpm). The leak is located in the valve body, opposite from the valve bonnet, approximately " above the center of the valve seat; this is on the reactor vessel side of the valve. This valve is part of the ASME Class 2 pressure boundary. The 101 valve is the isolation valve to the reactor vessel CRD drive housing.

Received a report from the field that both interlock doors on U2 RB 595 elevation from RFP room to RB were open at the same time. The doors were immediately closed. Field Supervisor confirmed the RB 595' side door is not functioning properly.

At 1012 CDT 12APR2014, Dresden Unit 2 automatically scrammed on TR-2 sudden pressure relay actuation. All rods inserted to their full-in positions. Following the Reactor Scram, the 'A' reactor recirculation pump did not run back to minimum speed automatically. Operators took action to run the recirculation pump to minimum speed manually. All other systems operated as expected. Reactor vessel inventory and pressure are being maintained in automatic. The cause of the scram was due to a trip of the sudden pressure relay for Main Power Transformer 2. Troubleshooting is in progress to determine the cause.

At 10:37 an employeereported to the WEC SRO that the Door 247 (AUX BLDG CORRIDOR FROM AIRLOCK J-17) Magnetic Lock was non-functional. The employee was passing through door 247 when another individual was able to open Door 248 (RB side access to Airlock J-17 and gain access to the airlock. both doors were open for approximately 5 seconds. The employee took control of door 247, restricted access and notified the WEC SRO. OCC MOM was contacted and EMD technicians responded to assess the deficiency. Tool pouch maintenance was authorized to perform repair. Based on discussion with the EMD manager, the cause of the malfunction was related to a fastener disengaging and preventing the magnetic lock from holding door 247 closed. The construction of othe assembly is such that the proximity switch (which reports door status to the door logic) is fastened to the door with 6 fasteners. A steel plate is fastened to the proximity switch with one fastener (the plate is used to enforce the magnetic lock function). The fastener for the steel plate had disengaged, which prevents the magnetic lock from holding the door closed. Sequence of events: -person on RB side pushes button (this prevents the AB side mag lock from deenergizing, however the interlock is not enforced due to the degraded steel plate fastener). -RB side person has to open a fire door before they open door 248 causing a delay in opening door 248 and the logic sensing that door 248 is open (logic triggers awareness alarms when a door is sensed open by the logic). -at the same time, person on AB side pushes button and opens door 247 (logic ignores this and maglock remains energized since a RB button was pushed first, however the maglock function is not enforced due to the degraded steel plate fastener). -RB side person opens door 248 since all permissives are met. awareness alarms do not sound until door 248 is open, but only sounds on AB side (per design). Door 247 is already open. -personnel take action to close both doors and contacted Operations to report deficiency. Door function: Ventilation Barrier Review: Impact on ventilation Systems: Doors #247 and #248 are part of Airlock No. J-17. Airlock No. J-17 separates the Unit 2 Reactor Building general access area at floor elevation 710'-6" from Auxiliary Building Chemistry Lab/Office Area. The ventilation system(s) affected (VR and VL) are designed to maintain overall ambient temperatures in conformance with equipment requirements, and to maintain airflow patterns from accessible areas to potentially contaminated areas to provide protection from radioactive particulates. Normally Doors # 247 and # 248 are interlocked so both cannot be opened at the same time per Drawing A-447. Therefore, when door #247 is impaired, door #248 must be closed. Flood Barrier Review: Impact of Flood Protected Areas: Certain doors and structures are credited as flood barriers as shown on UFSAR Figures 3.4-1 and 3.4-2. The subject door is located above grade at elevation 710'-6" thus is not credited as a flood barrier. HELB Barrier Review: Impact of HELB protected area: Doors #247 and #248 are part of Airlock No. J-17. Airlock No. J-17 separates the Unit 2 Reactor Building general access area at floor elevation 710'-6" from Auxiliary Building Chemistry Lab/Office Area. The Unit 2 Reactor Building general access area at floor elevation 710'-6" is classified as EQ harsh subzone H4A per UFSAR Figure 3.11-3 sheet 8. The Auxiliary Building Chemistry Lab/Office Area is classified as EQ mild zone N1 per UFSAR Figure 3.11-5 sheet 4. AR 1570731 identified an issue with the latchsets associated with the secondary containment airlock doors that are shielding doors (including doors #247 and #248). In order for doors #247 and #248 to serve as HELB barriers they must remain closed when subject to loads associated with HELB pressure and a seismic event. The pressure acting on doors #247 and #248 due to a postulated HELB in the Unit 1 Reactor Building would act to open them (reference drawing A-185). For these doors to remain closed during a postulated HELB the latchset must be capable of withstanding the loads associated with HELB pressure and a seismic event. Similar latchsets were evaluated in Design Analysis L-001661; however this design analysis is only applicable to regular doors and not shielding doors. The loads acting on the shielding doors include the door weight, HELB, and Seismic which are significantly greater than the loads acting on regular doors. This is primarily due to the shield doors being significantly heavier than the regular doors. Design Analysis L-001661 documents that the latchsets can accommodate a load of 1124 pounds, which exceeds the HELB and seismic loads acting on regular doors. However this load capacity is less than the HELB & seismic loads acting on the above shield doors. Thus the shield doors #247 and #248 should not be credited as HELB barriers. The regular door #886 provides access to shield door #248, and this door is credited as the HELB barrier for Airlock No. J-17. Door #886 opens into the Unit 2 RB general access area per drawing A-185, so a helb would force door #886 closed. Missile Barrier Review: Impact on Missile Protected area: only plant doors #19 and #20 are credited as missile barriers. Thus door #247 is not credited as a missile barrier. Occupational Radiation Protection Barrier Review: Impact of RPA: Door 248 must remain closed when door 247 is open to prevent the potential spread of contamination. Post-Accident Radiation EQ Barrier Review: Impact of equipment qualification: Doors #247 and #248 are part of Airlock No. J-17. Airlock No. J-17 separates the Unit 2 Reactor Building general access area at floor elevation 710'-6" from Auxiliary Building Chemistry Lab/Office Area. The Unit 2 Reactor Building general access area at floor elevation 710'-6" is classified as EQ harsh subzone H4A per UFSAR Figure 3.11-3 sheet 8. The Auxiliary Building Chemistry Lab/Office Area is classified as EQ mild zone N1 per UFSAR Figure 3.11-5 sheet 4. Also Doors #247 and #248 are shielding doors per the Door Schedule, drawing A-447. Also per Calc L-002522 the calculated accident dose for EQ harsh subzone H4A (7.89x10E6 rads) which is greater than the calculated accident dose for EQ mild zone N1 (3.82x10E2 rads). Thus Doors #247 and #248 are credited as post-accident radiation EQ barriers. Therefore, Door #248 shall remain closed when Door #247 is open (impaired).

At 1209 CDT 03 May 2014, Dresden Unit 2 automatically scrammed on Turbine/Generator Trip while performing an Automatic Voltage Regulator channel swap. All rods inserted to their full-in positions. Following the Reactor Scram. All systems operated as expected. Reactor vessel inventory and pressure are being maintained in automatic. Troubleshooting is in progress to determine the cause of the scram.

MMD was transitioning through HPCI interlock doors and both doors were opened at the same time. MMD controlled the doors when this was realized and immediately shut the HPCI elevator side door. The door and interlock lights appeared to function properly, but failed when challenged.
The A VE Compressor start alarm came in on the U-1 PPC when we realized that it did not make sense. We checked the PPC Point AEER_HVAC _REFRG_A PPC point which showed the compressor was off.
During performance of 9069.01, Shutdown Service Water Operability Test, 1SX01PC tripped approximately 36 seconds after started. 19:04 -Started SX pump 1SX01PC. 19:05 - 1SX01PC pump tripped.
During the B2R18 CRDM UT inspections, an indication was discovered in penetration number 6. Indication is at 13.5 to 15 degrees with an thru wall dimension .217 to .222.
AT 10:42 NMP1 HAD A MOMENTARY LOSS OF SECONDARY CONTAINMENT DUE TO BOTH REACTOR BUILDING AIRLOCK DOOR BEING OPENED AT THE SAME TIME BY CONTRACTORS.

On 11-4-2014 on shift 2, Operations was attempting to perform QCOS 2300-15 HPCI Drain Pot Level Switch/Drain Valve Testing with the HPCI steam lines isolated for other LCO work. At the start of the surveillance, HPCI Turbine Inlet Drain Pot LS 2-2365 as-found position was Picked Up, as expected. HPCI Turbine Inlet Drain Pot LS 2-2365 failed to reposition (magnet switch drop out) when the drain pot was filled with clean demin water. Opened and reclosed AO 2-2301-31 via EST to facilitate depressurizing HPCI steam line, and re-performed the surveillance for drain pot LS 2-2365, and the level switch did reposition and cause the high level alarm to come in. However, proceeding through the surveillance, after the drain pot was drained again, LS 2-2365 failed to reposition (magnet switch did not pick back up.) LS 2-2365 appears to be stuck in the high level position; the high level alarm will not reset, and AO 2-2301-31 is still Open in response. This is a new level switch, having been replaced this past August when the same thing happened with the old one. Reference IR 01689318 for HPCI Turbine Inlet Drain Pot LS 2-2365 being stuck, failing to reposition on August 5, 2014, during performance of this surveillance. Surveillance failed; continued performance of the remainder of the surveillance for the other drain pot level switches.

Field Supervisor was notified by chemistry that during operation of the Turbine Building to Reactor Building Interlocks on the 3rd Floor of the Rx building, the Turb Bldg Side door was able to open while the Rx Bldg door was open. Field Supervisor was dispatched to investigate the interlock issue and found that the issue was intermittent. Pushing the buttons to operate the door interlock will not cause the Turb Bldg Door to open if any other door is open, Only when applying force on the Turb Bldg Door will this door open. Upon investigation the bottom magnet that engages the door appears to not be engaging when the door closes intermittently. If pushed closed further the magnet engages and the door will remain closed. All three doors were tested when all doors were closed and neither door could be pulled opened, only when you have D/P across the Turb Bldg Door will the interlock magnet be released.

On 12/11/14 at 09:50 while traveling to the refuel floor, through the U/2 - 352' Reactor Enclosure airlock, both airlock doors were opened. Two technicians carded in and entered into the airlock and the lead technician failed to verify that the first door was closed, secured and the blue light was off prior to opening the second door resulting in a local alarm. Upon receiving the alarm the doors were both immediately secured.

At 13:24, received a report from an EMD technician that 0XXDR402 (DOOR #402, RX BLDG GROUND FLOOR UNIT 2 FROM VESTIBULE R-21) and 0FPDR507 (Door #507, from Vestibule R-27 to U2 DG Corridor) were open at the same time. These doors are interlocked to maintain Secondary Containment function. SR 3.6.4.1.2 requires verification that one secondary containment access door in each access opening is closed. Since SR 3.6.4.1.2 was not met, LCO 3.6.4.1 was not met for the time that both doors were open (approximately 10 seconds). No movement of irradiated fuel, CORE ALTERATIONS, or OPDRVs were in progress. Entered and exited LCO 3.6.4.1 condition A, RA A.1 to restore secondary containment to OPERABLE status within 4 hours for approximately 10 seconds (the time that Doors #507 and #402 were simultaneously open). Field supervisor was dispatched and posted Door #402 as "Emergency Egress Only." The interlock and latching mechanism for Door #507 is suspected to be degraded such that when Door #507 is closed, the interlock logic will permit Door #402 to be opened. The resulting differential pressure between the Auxiliary Building and Reactor Building is sufficient to cause Door #507 to intermittently unlatch and open. LOS-FP-D1 was performed for Door #507, which satisfies TSR 3.7.o.1. Door #507 is OPERABLE as a fire barrier.

During the 2014 NRC Triennial Fire Protection inspection, the NRC requested breaker fuse coordination analysis for the RCIC valves 2E51-F045 and 2E51-F019 supplied by 250 VDC MCC 221Y. These RCIC valves can be operated from the Remote Shutdown Panel in case of a fire in the main control room. As described in IR 2421318, the concern is that for a fire in the control room, a short in the control circuit may cause the associated 250 VDC breaker to trip before the 10A protective fuse in the circuit blows. If the feed breaker trips before the protective fuse, the valve cannot be operated from the Remote Shutdown Panel unless the breaker is reset. RCIC operation from the RSP is the method credited in the FPR for vessel inventory make up in the event of a fire in the main control room. Engineering has completed a preliminary review of all 28 affected RCIC valves and RCIC instrumentation on the Remote Shutdown Panel (RSP) and identified a total of 16 division 1 valves (8 per Unit) that have been preliminary evaluated for the breaker/fuse coordination issue. The RCIC valves on the division 2 portion of the RSP (480 VAC) and the RSP Instrumentation (including flow and turbine speed) supplied by 125 VDC are not affected by the preliminary breaker/fuse coordination issue. In addition, the RCIC containment isolation valves are supplied by 480 VAC and are not affected by the issue. It is understood that fire can potentially cause spurious operation or breaker trip, prior to transferring control to the RSP. In addition, LaSalle must postulate that a spurious operation can occur on any one of the affected valves prior to arriving at the RSP. However, the characteristics and type of combustible cable used at LaSalle (IEEE 383 qualified thermoset instead of thermoplastic), the incipient fire development and the magnitude of the fire in the first four minutes of the event, and the results of recent NRC cable testing programs, it is very unlikely that a spurious operation or breaker trip would occur In the first four minutes of the event, but if the fault occurred, it would most likely be due to a single conductor fault to ground that causes the breaker to fail in its current position. The 16 affected valves were checked to see if they are in the correct position when the breaker trips. A summary of each affected valve and what it takes to eliminate the breaker coordination issue is as follows: Impact of no power to the following valves on Unit-1 1E51-F010 . is the normal suction source from the CST and is a normally open valve (will not affect RSP operations). 1E51-F022 . is the normally closed full flow test valve used to throttle RCIC pressure during quarterly testing in the CST to CST mode. Power would have to be restored or manually opened before the valve is used for testing. This valve would not stop RCIC injection to the reactor. 1E51-F046 . is a normally closed valve when RCIC is not in operation that provides lube oil cooling for the RCIC turbine. This valve will not open until the breaker is reset. Based on reviews as part of Extended Power Uprate (EPU) (not official Engineering document at this time) and room temperature there is approximately 3 hours of run time before reaching maximum recommended lube oil temp of 235 degrees. 1E51-F031 . Is the normally closed suction source from the suppression pool. With no power the valve will not be able to automatically open on a low CST level. Based on coping for station blackout there is approximately 4 hours before this swap occurs. There is CST level remaining prior to the need to swap over to the suppression pool. 1E51-F360 . is the normally latched open trip and throttle valve. With the valve being open a steam source is available to the turbine. Will still trip on mechanical overspeed of the turbine and cannot be electrically cycled open with no power. The valve is in the correct position for RSP operations. 1E51-F068 . is a normally open valve and is the steam return (exhaust) to the suppression pool. This is the correct position for RSP operations. With this valve open the turbine will have an available exhaust path. 1E51-F069 . is a normally open valve for the barometric condenser vacuum pump discharge. This is the correct position for RSP operations. With the valve open the removal of the non- condensable gases will still be available. 1E51-F080 . is a normally open vacuum breaker line isolation valve. This is the correct position for RSP operations. With the valve open air will still be allowed to be drawn into the exhaust line to prevent water hammer. Impact of no power to the following valves on Unit-2 2E51-F010 . is the normal suction source from the CST and is a normally open valve. This is the correct position for RSP operations. 2E51-F059 . is the normally closed full flow test valve used during quarterly testing in the CST to CST mode. Power would have to be restored or manually opened if using for pressure control. 2E51-F046 . is a normally closed valve when RCIC is not in operation that provides lube oil cooling for the turbine. Based on reviews as part of EPU (not official Engineering document at this time) there is approximately 3 hours of run time before reaching maximum recommended lube oil temp of 235 degrees. 2E51-F031 . Is the normally closed suction source from the suppression pool. With no power the valve will not be able to automatically open on a low CST level. Based on coping for station blackout there is approximately 4 hours before this swap occurs. There is CST level remaining prior to the need to swap over to the suppression pool. 2E51-F360 . is the normally open trip and throttle valve. With the valve being open a steam source is available to the turbine. Will still trip on mechanical overspeed of the turbine and cannot be electrical cycled open with no power. 2E51-F068 . is a normally open valve and is the steam return (exhaust) to the suppression pool. This is the correct position for RSP operations. With this valve open the turbine will have an available exhaust path. 2E51-F069 . is a normally open valve for the barometric condenser vacuum pump. With the valve open the removal of the non- condensable gases will still be available. This is the correct position for RSP operations. 2E51-F080 . is the normally open vacuum line isolation. With the valve open air will still be allowed to be drawn into the exhaust line to prevent water hammer. This is the correct position for RSP operations. In summary, based on the preliminary results, four breakers in Unit 1 need to be changed with a breaker that has a larger continuous amp rating and eight breakers per unit require a change to their trip settings. Going forward, NRC IN Notice 97-48 has been reviewed for inadequate or in appropriate interim FP Compensatory Measures and that guidance will be implemented as required. Tie to IR 02421318.

During performance of LOS-DG-M3, equipment operators noted a small leak (1 DPS) coming from casing of 2B EDG CWP (2E22-C002). Operators noted that the leak was not active when they first checked the pump. They surmise that as the pump was running the pressure grew great enough to overcome the rust/mung around the pinhole leak; also an indication that the leak has been intermittently active for quite some time. Pictures can be found at L:PicturesUnreviewed2B EDG CWP Casing Leak Provide the following known information necessary to properly assess the condition of the leak. (1) Identify Source of water or steam leak: Pump casing, suction side. (2) Location of Leak: a. Building: AB b. Elevation: 674' c. Room: Div 3 CSCS Pump Room (3) Quantify the Leak: Small Leak--1 drop / second (4) Impact of Leak (check all that apply): Corrosion Mineral Deposits Through wall Leak of pump casing (5) Impact to electrical equipment from steam leak None (6) Mitigating Actions (check all that apply): Other: Drops contained on pump skid.

At 19:39 the Operator At The Controls noted Secondary Containment differential pressure had risen to greater than -0.25 in of vacuum water gauge and requested placing Standby Gas Treatment in service for Reactor Building Differential Pressure Control. At 19:50 Operations started GTS Train "A" per N2-OP-52, F.1. 0 Maintaining Reactor Building Differential Pressure and N2-OP-61B, E.2.0 Startup 2GTS*FLT1A. At 19:56 Reactor Building Differential Pressure had been restored to > -0.25 inches of vacuum water gauge and the average is approximately -0.6 inches of vacuum water gauge. TS 3.6.4.1. was exited. After review of PI Historian Computer, environmental conditions of a wind shift and significant wind gusts changed at approximately 18:24, quickly causing the Reactor Building Differential Pressure to become less negative whereby conditions of TS 3.6.4.1.1 Surveillance Requirement of >= to -0.25 inches of vacuum water gauge was not satisfied. The condition was deemed to be reportable under Any event or condition that at the time of discovery could have prevented the fulfillment of the safety function of structures or systems that are needed to mitigate the consequences of an accident.
