During the Braidwood NRC FP inspection, an inspector identified a circuit deficiency for which a design basis fire in the Main Control Room could prevent the Pressurizer PORV Block Valves from being closed from the local control switches at their associated MCCs (Reference Braidwood IRs #02542045 and #02544447). Byron Engineering has reviewed this issue and determined that this issue is also applicable to Byron Station. The close coil seal-in contact connection to the Main Control Room is not completely isolated by the local/remote transfer switch, and a potential fire induced ground in the Main Control Room could clear the associated local control power fuses, which would prevent the valve from operating at the local control switch. For a Main Control Room fire, the concern is that a hot short could cause the PORV to spuriously open, and then a ground fault on the PORV Block Valve control circuit could prevent the Block Valve from being manually closed by operating the local control switch at the MCC. Section 2.4.3.2 of the Fire Protection Report (FPR) Safe Shutdown Analysis (SSA) generically addresses the Pressurizer PORVs and Block Valves as follows: "A "remote/local" isolation switch and control switch are provided for the block valve at its motor control center, located in the Division 11(21) electrical penetration area. The block valve can be closed by placing the "remote/local" isolation switch in "Local" and then closing the valve with the control switch provided." (Note that a similar statement is also included for the Div. 12(22) PORV Block Valves, with the exception that the Div. 12(22) MCCs are located in the Division 12(22) electrical penetration area.) Followed by: "In fire zones where one of the PORVs has a control cable present in the zone that can spuriously open the PORV and its associated block valve does not have AC power available, the PORV will be failed closed by pulling its control power fuse at its DC distribution panel." The current licensing basis in the SSA classifies the PORVs/Block Valves as a High/Low pressure interface. For High/Low pressure interface components, Section 2.4.1.5.2.d of the SSA states: "2-wire ungrounded dc circuit cable-to-cable proper polarity faults are considered to be credible, and must be evaluated." Procedural guidance for implementing the SSA requirements for an MCR fire is provided in BOP FR-1T38 and 1(2)BOA PRI-5. Step 19 on Page 6 of BOP FR-1T38, Fire Zone 2.1-0 Main Control Room 1D-75, credits closing a Pressurizer PORV Block Valve using the local control switch to mitigate the consequences of a fire-induced spurious opening of a Pressurizer PORV. Additionally, Procedure BOP FP-100T38 would be used in conjunction with Procedure 1(2)BOA PRI-5. Step 15.a.2 of Procedure 1(2)BOA PRI-5 directs the operator to close the block valves locally at their associated MCCs. Step 15.a.3 states that if any PORV block valve cannot be closed, then locally remove the PORV control power fuses to fail its associated PORV closed. Pulling the PORV fuses would prevent a conductor-to-conductor hot short from spuriously opening the valve; however, pulling the PORV fuses would not prevent another DC cable from having two cable-to-cable proper polarity faults with the PORV cable and spuriously energizing the PORV. Therefore, a fire-induced spurious opening of a PORV due to cable-to-cable hot shorts, along with inadequate separation of the local and remote control circuits for the Block Valves, could adversely affect the current mitigation strategy for spurious opening of a Pressurizer PORV due to a fire. A review of the PORV and BLOCK Valve circuits identified 8 additional zones, for a total of 9 fire zones, where both the PORV and Block Valve circuits are routed and could potentially be subject to this concern. The fire zones are as follows: 2.1-0 (Main Control Room) 3.2B-1 (LCSR Zone B-1) 3.2C-1 (LCSR Zone C-1) 3.2B-2 (LCSR Zone B-2) 3.2C-2 (LCSR Zone C-2) 3.3B-1 (UCSR Zone B-1) 3.3C-1 (UCSR Zone C-1) 3.3C-2 (UCSR Zone C-2) 3.3D-2 (UCSR Zone D-2)

Security was on the scene at 08:15 at U2 TB side door, looked through window, saw U2 Rx side door closed. Used card reader to open U2 TB side and when open, noticed that the U2 Rx side door was slightly ajar. Security immediately exited interlock and closed U2 TB side door, contacted supervisor. Security supervisor arrived on scene at 08:30. Noticed both doors slightly ajar and contacted MCR at 08:35 stating that both U2 RX/Turb 569' elev interlock doors were unintentionally opened by CBI work group. Dispatched operators to investigate and found both doors slightly open with the door mechanism pins discharged. Operators closed both interlock doors a short time later. Rx Bldg d/p remained at -0.65". The Main Control Room did not initially receive the 902-4 E-20 Rx/Turb 569 Intlk Doors Inop/Byp alarm. No message was displayed on the SER. The 902-4 E-20 alarm was eventually received in the Main Control Room about 20 minutes after the initial call from Security with both interlock doors still closed, and still no SER displayed. Also, the 902-4 E-20 alarm will not reset. OPS supervisor (Patel) verified power available to both interlock doors. ENTERED TS 3.6.4.1. Cond. A. RA A.1 at 0810 when security received their alarm. EXITED TS 3.6.4.1. Cond. A. RA A.1 at 0815 when both interlock doors were closed. Notified Shift Manager and Reg. Assurance for reportability.

During shutdown for A2R18 both the 2A and 2B Auxiliary Feedwater pumps started on Lo-2 SGWL in the 2C S/G. The low SGWL condition existed due to a loss of the Unit 2 Startup Feedwater pump due to a breaker trip and a manual trip of the 2A MDFWP due to high bearing temperature. All equipment started and functioned as designed.

Following VF exhaust fan trip dp had risen to less than 0.25 inches of vacuum water gauge (0PDI-VG001/101). Declared secondary containment INOPERABLE. Secondary Containment is UNAVAILABLE per maintenance rule VG-05. Entered the following LCO action: - LCO 3.6.4.1 Action A.1 - Restore secondary containment to an operable status in 4 hours. Secondary containment dp > 0 inches of vacuum H2O. Entered EOP-8 SECONDARY CONTAINMENT CONTROL. Secondary containment dp was.15 inches of vacuum H2O. 02:38 Briefed placing VG -A train in service due to secondary Cnmt. Received a report that an employee entered a secondary containment interlock and identified that both doors of the Unit 2 Chemistry corridor / Reactor Building interlock (doors 247 and 248) opened simultaneously. The employee immediately secured both doors in the interlock and notified the Main Control Room Supervisor. Both doors in the interlock were open for approximately 5 seconds. FIN team reported that there was no mechanical damage to the door or magnetic lock. FIN team suspects electrical relay for door 247 in not functioning.

During the 2016 Braidwood NRC CDBI Inspection, the inspection team requested information supporting the acceptability of locating the combustion air intake for the B-train AFW diesel engines in the turbine building. There was no specific concern of interest identified by the inspection team. During the review of available documentation related to the B-train AFW diesel engine air intake, it was identified that the documentation did not support operation of the diesel with HELB environmental conditions postulated in the turbine building. Specifically, prior evaluations did not account for air displacement by steam release in the event. Reviewing the current turbine building HELB analysis, the data provided for Main Steam, Heater Drain and Feedwater breaks on the 401' elevation indicate conditions in the area of the air intake would not support AFW diesel operation. The steam generated during the event displaces enough air in the area to drop the air mass fraction below the level necessary to support fuel combustion. The current Braidwood Design Basis requires protection of safe shutdown capabilities in the event of a piping failure combined with a single active failure with or without offsite power. The AFW system is essential for safe shutdown of the plant following piping failures in the main steam, heater drain and feedwater systems. Either AFW pump (A-train or B-train) is capable of supporting the safe shutdown function. Under the Main Steam break, steam release to the turbine building is terminated by prompt closure of the MSIV. This action protects the B-train AFW pump. Assuming a single active failure (MSIV failure to close), the B-train AFW pump would not be capable of operating due to the lack of combustion air at the intake. The safe shutdown function is maintained by the A-train AFW pump with or without offsite power. The Main Steam break does not challenge the HELB safe shutdown function. Under the Heater Drain system break, the current turbine building HELB GOTHIC model was utilized to determine actual air mass fractions available on the 401' elevation of the turbine building. The current GOTHIC model uses very conservative M&E releases since the installation of the new HELB dampers provided sufficient protection of safety related equipment to preclude the need to further refine break flows. The current modeled Heater Drain system break flows were left excessively conservative since the new HELB barriers could accommodate the resulting conditions. To ascertain the actual environmental conditions near the B-train AFW diesel, the GOTHIC model was adjusted using more realistic break flows established during the prior HELB resolution effort. The environmental conditions resulting from the postulated Heater Drain system break using break flows from prior evaluations supports 1B AFW diesel engine operation. There is sufficient air density in the turbine building near the intake for proper engine combustion. Under the Feedwater break, the break occurs in the area of the B-train AFW combustion air intake and there is no automatic isolation feature that would prevent undesirable conditions in the turbine building. In this event, a single failure could involve failure of the A-train AFW system which would result in a failure of the safe shutdown AFW function. Braidwood Engineering has reviewed the feedwater system piping stress analyses and confirmed piping meets HELB analysis related stress allowable to preclude pipe breaks in the turbine building. Braidwood Engineering is currently reviewing associated piping support calculations to confirm the piping supports maintain structural integrity for the piping loads generated by the analysis. At this time, several supports have been identified with pipe applied loads in excess of design basis support load allowable values. A Technical Call was completed with appropriate piping support analysis subject matter experts. The consensus of the Technical Call was that the use of alternative pipe system analysis combined with detailed analysis of individual pipe supports would produce acceptable results that demonstrate feedwater piping breaks need not be postulated. Based on this information, the AFW function supporting safe shutdown can be considered protected from the effects of a turbine building HELB.

During the 2016 Braidwood NRC CDBI Inspection, the inspection team requested information supporting the acceptability of locating the combustion air intake for the B-train AFW diesel engines in the turbine building. There was no specific concern of interest identified by the inspection team. The question is also applicable to Byron station since the system design is the same as Braidwood. During the review of available documentation related to the B-train AFW diesel engine air intake, it was identified that the documentation did not support operation of the diesel with HELB environmental conditions postulated in the turbine building. Specifically, prior evaluations did not account for air displacement by steam release in the event. Reviewing the current turbine building HELB analysis, the data provided for Main Steam, Heater Drain and Feedwater breaks on the 401' elevation indicate conditions in the area of the air intake would not support AFW diesel operation. The steam generated during the event displaces enough air in the area to drop the air mass fraction below the level necessary to support fuel combustion. The current Byron Design Basis requires protection of safe shutdown capabilities in the event of a piping failure combined with a single active failure with or without offsite power. The AFW system is essential for safe shutdown of the plant following piping failures in the main steam, heater drain and feedwater systems. Either AFW pump (A-train or B-train) is capable of supporting the safe shutdown function. Under the Main Steam break, steam release to the turbine building is terminated by prompt closure of the MSIV. This action protects the B-train AFW pump. Assuming a single active failure (MSIV failure to close), the B-train AFW pump would not be capable of operating due to the lack of combustion air at the intake. The safe shutdown function is maintained by the A-train AFW pump with or without offsite power. The Main Steam break does not challenge the HELB safe shutdown function. Under the Heater Drain system break, the current turbine building HELB GOTHIC model was utilized to determine actual air mass fractions available on the 401' elevation of the turbine building. The current GOTHIC model uses very conservative M&E releases since the installation of the new HELB dampers provided sufficient protection of safety related equipment to preclude the need to further refine break flows. The current modeled Heater Drain system break flows were left excessively conservative since the new HELB barriers could accommodate the resulting conditions. To ascertain the actual environmental conditions near the B-train AFW diesel, the GOTHIC model was adjusted using more realistic break flows established during the prior HELB resolution effort. The environmental conditions resulting from the postulated Heater Drain system break using break flows from prior evaluations supports 1B AFW diesel engine operation. There is sufficient air density in the turbine building near the intake for proper engine combustion. Under the Feedwater break, the break occurs in the area of the B-train AFW combustion air intake and there is no automatic isolation feature that would prevent undesirable conditions in the turbine building. In this event, a single failure could involve failure of the A-train AFW system which would result in a failure of the safe shutdown AFW function. Braidwood Engineering has reviewed the feedwater system piping stress analyses and confirmed piping meets HELB analysis related stress allowable to preclude pipe breaks in the turbine building. Byron/Braidwood Engineering and EOCs are currently reviewing associated piping support calculations to confirm the piping supports maintain structural integrity for the piping loads generated by the analysis. At this time, several supports have been identified with pipe applied loads in excess of design basis support load allowable values. A technical call was completed by Braidwood engineering with appropriate piping support analysis subject matter experts. The consensus of the Technical Call was that the use of alternative pipe system analysis combined with detailed analysis of individual pipe supports would produce acceptable results that demonstrate feedwater piping breaks need not be postulated. Based on Braidwood's information, the AFW function supporting safe shutdown can be considered protected from the effects of a turbine building HELB.

At approximately 1730 while entering reactor building 261' from RP access, both airlock doors were opened at the same time. Prior to opening the first door I performed the 5 second wait and carded in then opened door. As I was entering the airlock the inner door was opened by 3 contractors who immediately shut the inner door. Both doors were opened for approximately 1 second. After proceeding through inner door contractors recognized that they made an error and exited the building properly.
Entered ABN-1, Reactor Scram due to excessive leakage from the Delta Recirc Pump. The reactor was manually scrammed.

At 1104 hours, the unit NLO was sent to investigate a steam leak on unit 2 517' elevation. The steam leak is upstream of the 2-2301-29 AOV. The leak appears to be a through wall leak on HPCI piping. There is a small amount of steam coming out from under the pipe insulation and condensing on nearby pipes to produce approximately 15 dpm. The drops are not falling on any equipment and not blocking any walkway. Without removing the lagging it is impossible to tell where the exact leak is. A catch was installed to collect the condensation and route it to a floor drain.

This IR identifies a nonconforming condition in our design such that ventilation openings in the L line wall above 451' elevation and the RWST tank roof hatches are not considered to be adequately protected from tornado missiles as described in our licensing basis. The NRC has provided guidance for such issues in Enforcement Guidance Manual (EGM) 15-002, ENFORCEMENT DISCRETION FOR TORNADO-GENERATED MISSILE PROTECTION NONCOMPLIANCE, and Interim Staff Guidance DSS-ISG-2016-01, Clarification of Licensee Actions in Receipt of Enforcement Discretion Per Enforcement Guidance Memorandum EGM 15-002. This IR documents the nonconforming condition and the implementation of EGM 15-002 and DSS-ISG-2016-01 to transition the SSC's from inoperable to operable but nonconforming. This IR documents that initial compensatory measures are in place, tracks development of longer term comprehensive compensatory measures (within 60 days) and tracks resolution of issue (by 6/10/2018). GDC Criterion 4 requires SSCs important to safety shall be appropriately protected against dynamic effects including missiles. The Braidwood SER states that all safety related systems and components are located within tornado-missile-protected structures, or are provided with tornado-missile barriers or other protection (such as burial underground), or are orientated so that tornado missiles do not present a safety hazard with the exception of the DG exhaust stacks, and MS safety and relief valve exhaust stacks. As described in UFSAR Section 3.3.2.2.2 all siding and roof decking above the floor at elevation 451 feet is designed to blow off at tornado pressures exceeding 105 psf. The subject ventilation openings in the L-line wall above 451' elevation and the RWST hatches are not fully protected from tornado missiles nor accepted as adequately protected during original licensing. The following items could be impacted by tornado missiles entering the 0A and 0B MCR turbine building intake openings: Main control room pressurization, main control room ductwork and dampers, chilled water to the VC coils, main control room radiation monitors. The following items could be impacted by tornado missiles entering the Division 11 and 21 MEER rooms: Exhaust from the MEER (affects room cooling and MCR pressure), exhaust from a battery room, conduits and cabinets associated with the battery chargers and DC bus. The following items could be impacted by tornado missiles entering the Division 12 and 22 MEER rooms: Exhaust from the MEER (affects room cooling and MCR pressure), MEER supply fan and ductwork, battery room exhaust, and the instrument inverter cabinets. The Aux Feed Diesel exterior exhaust stacks (which extend from the roofline) could be impacted by tornado missiles. While we have analyses on these impacts, they do not use a NRC accepted methodology to evaluate the impact and effects. The RWST roof access opening Bilco hatch is fabricated from sheet metal that is not designed to prevent all postulated tornado missiles from entering the tank. The following items could be impacted by tornado missiles entering the RWST roof access. The tank pressure boundary is 24" thick concrete and is designed to withstand an external tornado missile impact. Thus a missile that enters the tank will not adversely impact the tank pressure boundary. The 6" RWST recirculation pipe, 3" overflow pipe, and 24" suction pipe are located inside the tank are approximately 130 degrees around the tank away from the hatch opening. Although the likelihood of a tornado missile traversing through the unprotected opening and damaging equipment resulting in a loss of function is low, it is possible that a tornado missile hit on one or more of the items listed above could result in the loss of the associated Technical Specification safety function. The NRC has issued EGM 15-002 for when an operating power licensee does not comply with a plant's current site specific licensing basis for tornado generated missile protection. If the licensee cannot perform the applicable TS LCO required action(s) or restore compliance within the completion time allowed by the LCO, the EGM provides enforcement discretion when a licensee implements initial compensatory measures prior to expiration for the time allowed by the LCO. As described in DSS-ISG-2016-01 the initial compensatory measures should be in place and the action for the EGM should be verified as current and readily deployable within a very short time frame. The DSS-ISG states: "The following initial compensatory measures should be completed before the expiration of the TS action statement allowed outage time: 1. Verify that procedures are in place and training is current for performing actions in response to a tornado, such as: a. The affected unit's abnormal and emergency operating procedures addressing tornados/high winds, and the loss of the tornado missile vulnerable equipment. b. The affected unit's Diverse and Flexible Coping Strategies (FLEX) equipment and procedures, if available. If site FLEX equipment and procedures are not available, specific measures should be put in place with equipment staged, procedures written, and training completed for actions to lessen the likelihood of tornado missile effects on the affected SSCs, or for prompt recovery of SSC function from tornado missile effects. 2. Verify that procedures are in place and training is current for the following actions to be taken if a tornado watch is issued for the area, such as: a. Remove, relocate, or secure potential missiles. b. From a work management/configuration control perspective, protect equipment important to maintaining safe shutdown conditions. c. Promptly complete or restore equipment from maintenance activities in progress on equipment important to maintaining safe shutdown conditions. d. Restore equipment important to maintaining safe shutdown conditions if undergoing maintenance or testing, if possible. e. Verify equipment is ready to use by visual inspection, surveillances and preventive maintenance are current, and review pending equipment maintenance requests. 3. Verify that procedures are in place and training is current for actions to be taken if a tornado warning is issued for the area, such as: a. Warning and protection strategies for site personnel. b. Strategies for prompt damage assessment and initiation of restorative actions (e.g., pre-staging of equipment and plant staff at safe, strategic locations to promptly implement any necessary mitigative actions). 4. Establish a heightened level of station awareness and preparedness relative to identified tornado missile vulnerabilities. This can be accomplished by including: a. A description of the nonconforming SSC(s) and the associated compensatory measures in the shift manager turnover notes. b. Discussing these actions during shift turnover briefings, and c. Including the compensatory actions in the operability determination documentation maintained in the control room." The shift manager is aware of these initial compensatory actions and has adequate procedures and training to assure these actions are taken. As part of long term corrective actions, additional measures are planned to more efficiently assimilate these actions into site processes as well as train others. Therefore, with the writing of this IR and including this IR in the shift manager turnover briefings, these initial compensatory measures are considered current and readily deployable and thereby meet the requirements of EGM implementation. Per the DSS-ISG: "Once enforcement discretion due to inoperability of SSC(s) for tornado missile protection considerations is implemented, the SSCs that were determined to be inoperable should be considered "operable but non-conforming." To document the implementation of the EGM, licenses should declare (log) the inoperability of the SSC(s), establishment of initial compensatory measures, and use of EGM 15-002 to establish justification for transition of SSC(s) from inoperable to operable but non-conforming. Additionally the licensee is expected to inform the resident inspector. The enforcement discretion does not relieve the licensees of any reporting requirements required in 10 CFR for inoperable TS-required SSCs. The operable but non-conforming condition would be justified by the licensee's implementation of initial compensatory measures, with the understanding that comprehensive compensatory measures would be implemented within 60 days." Therefore, further actions to document implementation of EGM 15-002 include: 1. Review this IR in shift manager turnover briefings until longer term actions can be put in place regarding initial compensatory actions. Operating to confirm that initial compensatory actions are in place and that issue has been added to shift manager turnover, in Operations review of IR. 2. Declare (log) the inoperability of the SSC(s), establishment of initial compensatory measures, and use of EGM 15-002 to establish justification for transition of SSC(s) from inoperable to operable but non-conforming. 3. Inform resident inspector. 4. Determine reporting requirements required in for inoperable TS-required SSCs. This will be included in Operations response in IR. 5. Create action to develop longer term comprehensive compensatory measures, due in 60 days. Create standing PHC agenda item to bring status of long term actions to PHC, due in two weeks. Regarding longer term comprehensive compensatory measures, the DSS-ISG further states: "For longer term comprehensive compensatory measures, the licensee will have extended time to evaluate specific strategies for protection of affected, opposite train, and alternate equipment; restoration plans including consideration for additional equipment to include under FLEX or other onsite inventories; and operational considerations in recognition to the extent of the nonconformance. Comprehensive compensatory measures should be completed as soon as practicable, but no later than 60 days after identification of the affected SSC(s) for enforcement discretion to remain in effect. The following comprehensive compensatory measures should be completed no later than 60 days following identification of nonconformance(s), such as: 1. Maintain initial compensatory actions, as appropriate. 2. Implement additional detailed actions. Examples may include specific measures with equipment staged, procedures written, and training completed for actions to lessen the likelihood of tornado missile effects on the affected SSCs or for prompt recovery of SSC function from tornado missile effects. Ensure any equipment and procedures necessary for these compensatory actions are staged in areas protected from exposure to tornado events, but will be promptly accessible. In order for enforcement discretion to apply, the licensee's additional actions should demonstrate a discernable change from its pre-discovery actions. Temporary modifications may be chosen to reduce the likelihood of damage to affected SSCs from tornado missiles, but are not expected for initial compensatory measures nor required for comprehensive compensatory measures." 6. Create action to fully resolve issue by June 10, 2018, per EGM 15-002.

MMD personnel opened the RB side door to enter the airlock in unison with an RP Technician exiting the Airlock to the Turbine Building. HURB to be completed to understand the details, determine why the barriers in place did not work and what HU behavior shortfalls led to the event.

UPS 162 B Transferred to Bypass to load . RPS 11 Instrumentation Power Power was lost at 2357 and RPS bus 11 was repowered on the bypass-to-load and stable several seconds later. SOP 40.1 Loss of RPS 11 (ABNORMAL-OP) was entered at 0000 on 7/29/16. The high Drywell pressure signal for Channel 11 was reset and the half scram was reset at 0006. SOP 40.1 was executed with some exceptions: 1. Control Room Emergency ventilation did not actuate as expected. A Control Room Vent Rad Monitor Off Normal annunciator L1-4-2 was received and found to be caused by an equipment failure indicator on 11 Control Room Vent Rad Monitor. 12 CR Vent Rad Mon Remains Operable. 2. ATWS Channel 11 Trouble annunciator F2-4-2 was received as expected but could not be cleared. Computer point F108 ATWS CH 11 LOGIC PWR indicates failed. 3. Both ECs (Isolation Condensers) isolated on high steam flow (unexpected). This resulted in a "commence a shutdown in 1 hour and be Cold S/D in 10 hour" LCO entry. This was exited 0041, resulting in a 7 day LCO for 11 EC Inoperable and when 11 EC was restored to Standby at 0045, No LCOs were in effect for the EC Systems. A shutdown was NOT commenced. The SDM and Duty Team were informed and the decision was made to man the OCC. The team has reset all alarms with the exception of the: 1.CU System Isolation, K3-4-4, 2.Control Room Vent Rad Monitor Off Normal, L1-4-2, 3.ATWS Channel 11 Trouble, F2-4-2 4.RPS UPS 162 Trouble, A3-1-2

Test results of the charcoal sample taken from the CREVS upstream bank of charcoal did not meet Acceptance Criteria (AC). The AC is <0.5% Methyl Iodide Penetration. The test results were 0.65% Methyl Iodide Penetration and does not meet the AC. Specifically, the AC per Step H.3. of DTS 5750-05 "Control Room Air Filter Unit Performance Requirements" is as follows, "The laboratory test confirms a Methyl Iodide penetration of <0.5% Methyl Iodide Penetration (overall) when tested at 30C, 70% humidity. (Tech Spec 3.7.4.2 and 5.5.7.) (W-6, W-7)." The CREVS upstream bank charcoal Sample was from Lot 69 / Batch 07 and removed per WO# 01773006-02. The test results are tracked per WO# 01773006-03. The said Lot / Batch has previously met AC per PM 00008808-01. The test vendor was challenged and was confident their test is accurate and was performed by an ANSI N45.2.6, Level III Engineer and approved by and ANSI N45.2.6, Level III Approver. The test vendor cannot retest the sample as well.
MCC 234V4 is Not energized Possible cause Unit 2 Trip at Byron Station on 10/12/16

On December 10, 2016 at 0848, Nine Mile Point Unit 1 manually SCRAMMED the Reactor due to high vibrations on the Main Turbine. Following the automatic scram, the High Pressure Coolant Injection (HPCI) System automatically initiated as expected. At Nine Mile Point Unit 1, a HPCI System actuation signal on low Reactor Pressure Vessel (RPV) level is normally received following a reactor scram, due to level shrink. HPCI is a flow control mode of the normal feedwater systems, and is not an Emergency Core Cooling System. At 0849, RPV level was restored above the HPCI System low level actuation set point and the HPCI System initiation signal was reset. Pressure control was established on the Turbine Bypass Valves, the preferred system. No Electromatic Relief Valves actuated due to this scram.

This IR identifies a non-conforming condition with the EDG exhaust stacks with respect to tornado missile protection and, if they are determined to be inoperable, provides for application of NRC enforcement discretion to allow diesel generators E1, E2, E3 and E4 to be returned to an operable status. As documented in IR 322722, the EDG exhaust stacks at PB extend approximately 7 feet above the roof of the diesel building and are not protected against tornado missiles. This was determined to be acceptable at the time the IR was evaluated because it was assumed only one missile strike had to be considered and the plant can be safely shutdown with three diesels. NRC actions since that time have shown that multiple missiles need to be considered and that all four EDGs need to be capable of performing their design function following a tornado. Peach Bottom's licensing basis for tornado missile protection is contained in the following: UFSAR Section C.2.4: "Components which directly affect the ultimate safe shutdown of the plant are located either in reinforced concrete structures or underground for tornado protection. These components include . . . standby diesel generators." UFSAR Section H.2.1: "Essential structures and equipment are designed to performance standards which enable the facility to withstand, without loss of capability to protect the public, the additional forces that might be imposed by natural phenomena such as . . . tornados." UFSAR Section 8.5 states that each diesel generator is protected against natural phenomena, such as tornadoes. Since the exhaust stacks are an integral component of the EDG and are not protected against tornado missiles, the design does not meet the licensing basis and a non-conforming condition exists. As stated in OP-AA-108-115, "Operability Determinations" (which is based on NRC Inspection Manual 0326), in order to be considered operable, a component must be capable of performing its specified safety function within the required range of design physical conditions. IR 322722 assignment 03 determined that a design basis missile strike of the upper half of the exhaust stack could bend the stack sufficiently to affect operation of the engine. The NRC reviewed a similar issue at a plant with a similar licensing basis (Point Beach) and stated in TIA 2012-07 (ML12115A080) that EDGs are expected to survive a tornado with the capability to perform their safety function intact. Tornados are part of the required range of design physical conditions in which the EDGs must be able to operate. The NRC reviewed issues related to tornado missile protection in RIS 2015-06 (ML15020A419). Licensees that identify tornado generated missile non-compliances that result in a TS LCO required shutdown may receive enforcement discretion. The EGM allows SSCs to be restored to an operable but non-conforming status provided certain compensatory measures are taken as detailed in DSS-ISG-2016-01 (ML15348A202). SSCs that are determined to be inoperable should be declared (logged) as inoperable, the initial compensatory measures should be implemented, and the SSC should be declared operable but non-conforming by applying EGM 15-002. Additional compensatory measures specific to the vulnerability must be implemented within 60 days. The enforcement discretion will remain in effect for 5 years after the issuance of RIS 2015-06 (6/10/15) for Group B plants, which includes Peach Bottom. The enforcement discretion does not relieve the licensee of any reporting requirements. The resident inspector has been informed of this issue and of the intent to utilize enforcement discretion in accordance with EGM 15-002. Extent of Condition After issuance of ISG-2016-01 in February 2016, Exelon Corporate Engineering initiated a project to identify the licensing basis for tornado missiles at all Exelon plants. Corporate Engineering also contracted with S&L to perform plant walkdowns at Exelon sites to identify potential vulnerabilities. S&L has completed their walkdown at Peach Bottom and a report of potential vulnerabilities has been provided to the site. Because S&L was not fully knowledgeable of the licensing and design basis of the plant, additional review is being performed by PEDM to identify any non-compliances. Cause This is a design issue not recognized during the original licensing of the plant. Other plants have identified similar non-conformances, and the NRC determined that a period of enforcement discretion was appropriate to allow the industry to resolve the non-compliances. Related Issues at other Exelon plants IR 2673848 and IR 2673854 were initiated at Byron and Braidwood for nonconforming conditions related to tornado missile protection.

Received report that an employee entered a secondary containment interlock and identified that both doors of the Unit 2 Reactor Building 710' Elevation Reactor Building 3 Way Air Lock (doors 507 and 402) opened simultaneously. The employee immediately secured both doors in the interlock and notified the Main Control Room Supervisor. Both doors in the interlock were open for approximately 5 seconds. With both doors open, TS SR 3.6.4.1.2 was not met. This rendered secondary containment inoperable per TS 3.6.4.1. Reactor Building differential pressure, as observed in the Main Control Room, has remained less than -0.25" H20 at all times. Entered and exited the TS 3.6.4.1 LCO Required Action RA A.1, Restore secondary containment to OPERABLE status within 4 hours for both units. MIF was in progress at the time of this event, and was temporarily suspended and re-entered with LOP-AA-03, Attachment D (Unit 1 and 2) for Moving Irradiated Fuel in the Secondary Containment re-verified. The air lock has been secured/blocked.

Investigated report of possible failure of the Unit 2 595' RB door interlock circuit. Determined the reactor building door (2-0020-152) is not always actuating the interlock circuit correctly, potentially allowing the turbine building door to open with the reactor building door open. Investigation by EMD determined relay 2-0020-152-DL-2 is intermittently sticking and shows signs of overheated and damaged contacts. Noted similar discoloration on relay 2-0030-119-DL-1, although that relay does not have the obviously damaged contacts. A separate IR will be written to replace that relay. Refer to 4E-6833A Sheet 3 and 4E-6832A Sheet 2.

On February 13, 2017 at 2309 CST, Unit 1 Reactor Automatic Scram signal was received due to Turbine Control Valves Fast Closure. The turbine trip was due to the main generator trip on Differential Current. The 'U' safety relief valve actuated in the relief mode on the turbine trip, and has subsequently reset with tailpipe temperature returning to normal. Plant is in a stable condition with reactor pressure being maintained by the Turbine Bypass valves. Reactor water level is being controlled with feedwater.

Entered a secondary containment interlock and identified that both doors of the Unit 1 Reactor Building 710' Elevation Reactor Building Air Lock (doors 225 and 226) opened simultaneously. Immediately secured both doors in the interlock and notified the Main Control Room Supervisor. Both doors in the interlock were open for approximately 5 seconds.

Received several annunciators associated with transient on 138 kV off site source. Transient resulted in the following: VF fans tripped, VC-A chiller tripped, VD exhaust fan 1VD02CA tripped, FPM skid isolation valves shut, H2O2 isolations valves shut, 1SA029 Cnmt SA Outboard Isol shut, NSPS Inverter Trouble (loss of sync), SX-A pump auto started, ERAT SVC tripped. . After multiple transients the 138 kV line de-energized and Div 1 Bus fast transferred to RAT.

The MSIV results for As Found Local Leak Rate Testing: Alpha line: Inboard = 10,632.08 sccmOutboard = 39,861.44 sccm Bravo line: Inboard = 21,611.35 sccmOutboard = 23,255.60 sccm Charlie line: Inboard = 19,396.70 sccmOutboard = 16,297.92 sccm Delta line: Inboard = 53,921.61 sccmOutboard = 59,698.8 sccm As Found Min Path = 102,463 sccmAs Found Max Path = 142,212.5 sccm The MSIV's for Clinton Power Station have two Tech Spec limits for past operability. The first is the valve with the least As-Found leakage (Minx-Path) in each line must be below 100 scfh (47,195 sccm). The second is the As-Found combined leakage of the best valve in each line must be below 200 scfh (94,390 sccm) when tested at Pa to 1.1 Pa (9 to 9.9 psig). First Tech Spec Requirement per line leakage: As Found Min Path leakage for the MSIV that exceeded 47,195 sccm limit: Delta Inboard 53,921.61 sccm and Outboard 59,698.8 sccm Second Tech Spec Requirement total combined < 94,390 sccm: Alpha = 10,632.08 sccm + Bravo = 21,611.35 sccm + Charlie 16,297.92 sccm + Delta 53,921.61 sccm = 102,463 sccm

Placed Mode Switch in Shutdown. Entered Reactor Scram Off-Normal and EOP-Stationed Tapia as Incident Assessor. 20:40 - Manually tripped Main Turbine and Generator. 20:43 - Established level band level 3 to level 8 and pressure band 500 - 800 psig. 20:50 - Removed CP E from Rinse and removed CP D from service. CP A, C, & F are in service. 20:51 - Placed TBCCW Pump and Heat Exchanger B in service. 20:55 - Started Condenser Vacuum Pump B, commenced shutdown SJAE B. 21:08 - SJAE B shutdown complete through 3215.01 step 8.1.4. 16. 21:30 - New pressure band 400 - 600 psig. 22:00 - Plant conditions are stable, exiting Scram Off-Normal and EOP-1. 22:13 - Shifted Gland Seal to Aux steam per 3107.01 section 8.1.1.2 22:26 - Main Turbine is reset. Still need to reset 1PA06J. 23:00 - Completed Main Turbine shutdown per 3105.01. Turbine oil heater is energized.

MMD/RP commenced work on RT 'B' pump at approximately 21:17 June 1, 2017 . At approximately 02:30 6/2/2017, an announcement was made stating the plant was entering startup requiring Primary and Secondary Containment to be established. When questioned, the RP Tech stated that they did not hear this announcement. Plant entered Mode 2 at 02:41 6/2/2017 At 03:00 6/2/2017, an SRO was transiting to 762 AB West side from the CB East elevator on the 737 elevation. While going past RT 'B' pump room saw an RP Technician dressing out and another Maintenance Technician at the outside of RT 'B' Pump Room CA boundary. At that time the outer door was propped open. Upon looking into the RT pump room access saw the inner door was also propped open with welding cables routed into the pump room. At 03:01 the WCS was notified that these 2 doors were propped open. At 03:03, the CRS was notified that I discovered the inner and outer doors propped open to perform welding in RT 'B' Pump room. I went back to the pump room at about 03:10 to speak to MMD and was informed they were almost fully complete and I waited until both doors were secured. I then informed the RP and Maintenance Technicians that the doors can only be opened one at a time since we are in Mode 2. I called the MCR at 03:23 to inform the CRS that both doors were now closed and cabling for the welding machine was removed. PBI-2017-05-045 was issued 5/9/2017 for door 1DR-190 and subsequently closed out 5/29/2017. PBI-2017-05-046 was issued 5/9/2017 for door 1DR-261. PBI-2017-05-46 was modified 6/2/2017 to include both doors being open (1DR-261 and 190), Security was notified to commence hourly fire tours. PBI-2017-05-046 was closed 6/2/2017 for both doors (1DR-261 and 1DR-190) after they were closed, Security was notified to secure hourly fire tours.
