SITE: HARRIS SUBJECT: UNANALYZED CONDITION DUE TO OPEN HIGH ENERGY LINE BREAK DOORS ICES #: Event Number: 51178 SUMMARY: On June 16, 2015 at 1145 EDT while in Mode 1 at 100% power steady-state conditions, two fire doors between the Reactor Auxiliary building (RAB) and steam tunnel were opened under administrative controls to support maintenance. These doors are credited in high energy line break equipment qualification and internal flooding analyses and opening of the doors is not addressed in the analyses. A high energy line break in the steam tunnel with the doors open could result in equipment in the RAB experiencing high temperature, pressure, or humidity beyond conditions analyzed for equipment qualification which has the potential to render redundant safety-related equipment inoperable. "The event was determined to be reportable on June 24, 2015 at approximately 1550 EDT]. During that reportability evaluation, it was determined that the doors may have been in a similar condition multiple times in the May-June time frame. "There was no adverse impact to public health and safety or to plant employees."

SITE: ARKANSAS NUCLEAR SUBJECT: UPDATE - SEISMIC MONITOR DECLARED NON FUNCTIONAL ICES #: Event Number: 51184 SUMMARY: This notification is being made as an event that will result in a major loss of emergency assessment capability, offsite response capability, or offsite communications capability (e.g. significant portion of control room indication, Emergency Notification System or offsite notification system.) The emergency preparedness plan requires seismic monitoring instruments to diagnose an earthquake for emergency action levels (EAL) HU6 (Natural or destructive phenomena affecting Protected Area) and HA6 (Natural and destructive phenomena affecting Vital Areas). At 2149 CST on June 26, 2015, the ACS-8003 seismic monitor was declared non-functional due to having a fault light indicated on the C529 seismic cabinet. The ACS-8001 seismic monitor had previously been declared non-functional due to the same condition. With these 2 monitors out of service, the seismic alarm capability is not available. ANO procedures provide compensatory measures of using offsite sources to obtain seismic data. The NRC Resident Inspector has been notified. * * * UPDATE ON 6/28/15 AT 1552 EDT FROM KENYON MCNEAILL TO DONG PARK * * * On 6/28/15 at 1232 CDT, batteries have been replaced in ACS-8001 and ACS-8003 seismic monitors. Both monitors have been restored to a fully functional status. Seismic alarm capability is restored and Emergency Assessment Capability has been restored. The licensee will notify the NRC Resident Inspector. Notified R4DO (Campbell).

During the Liquid Penetrant examination on the weld build up for CRDM Penetration 31, two indications were identified during the examination that exceed ASME Section III criteria. The first is a 9/32" rounded indication located at 270 degrees, at the intersection of the J-Groove Weld buildup and Nozzle buildup transition of the head to penetration. The second is a 0.10" linear indication located on the vertical portion of the penetration at 270 degrees and 3/16" down the penetration from the intersection of the J-Groove Weld buildup and Nozzle buildup transition. 0 Degrees is located at the outermost portion of the penetration on the flange side. The transition is the point where the vertical portion of the penetration meets the horizotal area of the reactor head. These two indications are documented in NDE report number 2015-240

MCR received unexpected alarm 5009-2A, Accl Excded Seis Sw/Oper Bas Earthqke, and 5009-3A Activated Seismic Recorder. Entered CPS 4301.01, Earthquake Off-normal. Stationed the Incident Assessor. Verified with Security no ground motion was felt onsite. USGS Earthquake website shows no seismic events at this same time. Contacted Braidwood Station, LaSalle Stations, Callaway, Duane Arnold and the National Earthquake Information Service (Don), no ground motion or seismic alarms were received or noted. Appendix A: Event Validation Display section A.2 performance revealed 1VT-EM005 Vert: -0.4170, E/W: -0.3006, and N/S: -0.3125 values exceeded both OBE and SSE Values. Area Operators were dispatched to perform a walk down of plant areas. All indications in the MCR appear normal for normal full power operation. 15:15 -- Per Appendix A Event Validation Criteria, the event is being classified as VALID per 4301.01 Earthquake Appendix A. (Step A.1.1 - If only 1 accelerometer triggered, and the Seismic Switch 1VT-EM014 alarmed, Then the alarm shall be treated as VALID until detailed Engineering analyses determines otherwise). However, based on the above information, declared Seismic Instrumentation INOPERABLE. Entered the following ORM Action Statement: - ORM 2.2.7 Action 3.2.7.A, Restore Seismic Instrumentation within 30 days or initiate a condition report.

Refer to IR 2623885. Completed an 8 Hour Non-emergency notification to the NRC via ENS # 51721 in accordance with for the loss of secondary containment. Per LS-AA-1110, REPORTABLE EVENT SAF 1.8: Event or Condition That Could Have Prevented Fulfillment of a Safety Function. Loss of secondary containment is considered reportable under. A breach of secondary containment is considered reportable if the following conditions are met: 1) secondary containment is required in the current mode or other specific condition; 2) secondary containment is declared inoperable in accordance with the plant's Technical Specifications; and 3) the reason(s) for inoperability is (are) not part of a planned evolution. Description: At 21:42 on February 9, 2016, Reactor Building differential pressure did not meet the required 0.25 inches of vacuum water gauge due to failure of the control system. At 22:05, the Unit 3 Reactor Building Ventilation System was secured and manually isolated. The Reactor Building differential pressure returned to ? 0.25 inches of vacuum water gauge at 22:07. This condition represents a failure to meet Surveillance Requirement 3.6.4.1.1. As a result, entry into Technical Specifications 3.6.4.1 condition A was made due to Secondary Containment being inoperable. This event is being reported in accordance with as a condition that could have prevented the fulfillment of a safety function. The NRC Resident Inspector has been notified.

Received unexpected annunciators 5015-1C LOW LEVEL LP HTR 2A and 5015-3C NOT FULLY CLOSED LP HTR 2A EMERG DRN VLVS. Entered CPS 4005.01 Loss of Feedwater Off-Normal. Initial reported reactor power was 99.2% and 3445 MW Thermal. Station Tapia as the IA Extraction Steam has automatically isolated to 2A, 3A, and 4A heaters and Feedwater temperature has begun to lower. Initial FW Temperature is 424.1F. 03:39 - Feedwater temperature is 413F and lowering, Reactor Power is 3463 MW Thermal. Reducing reactor power by lowing flow using both A and B flow control valves. Highest Reactor Power seen during the transient is 3482 MW Thermal for less than 2 minutes. The MELLA limit has been exceeded, Enter the following LCO actions. ITS LCO 3.2.1 Action A.1- Restore APLHGR to within limits in 2 hours ITS LCO 3.2.2 Action A.1-Restore MCPR to within limits in 2 hours ITS LCO 3.2.3 Action A.1- Restore LHGR to within limits in 2 hours ITS LCO evaluated by: Kalmer/Tapia Commence inserting control rods in reverse sequence to get back inside the MELLA limit. 03:45 - The plant has stabilized at approximately 3440 MW Thermal. Feedwater temperature is 401.5F 04:28 - Back below the MELLA limit. Reactor power is 96.7%, 3360 MW Thermal, and FW temperature is 395.8F. Exit ITS LCO 3.2.1, 3.2.2, 3.2.3 Plant stable, secure IA 04:52 - Based upon RE recommendation inserted control rods in reverse sequence to obtain FCL <99.7% on the 10 minute average. 05:00- Current status of controllers on 1PA05J are: MSDT: Normal; Setting - Auto; Position - Closed; Setpoint +6"; Actual 0" Emergency: Setting - Auto; Position - 30% open; Setpoint 0"; Actual 0" 6A HTR: Normal; Setting - Auto; Position - 55%; Setpoint +1" Emergency: Setting - Auto; Position - Closed; Setpoint +3"; Actual +1" 5A HTR: Normal; Setting - Manual; Position - Closed; Setpoint +6"; Actual - cycling Emergency; Setting - Auto; Position - Cycling 50%-100% open; Setpoint +1"; Actual +1 to +4 4A HTR: Normal; Setting - Auto; Position - Open; Setpoint +2"; Actual +4.5" Emergency; Setting - Auto; Position - Closed; Setpoint +6" 3A HTR: Normal; Setting - Auto; Position - Closed; Setpoint +4"; Actual +3" Emergency: Setting - Auto; Position - Closed; Setpoint +8" 2A HTR: Normal; Setting - Auto; Position - Open; Setpoint +2.2"; Acutal +6.2 Emergency; Setting - Auto; Position - 35% open; Setpoint +6.2

This issue reports NRC Severity Level IV NCV 2016001-03 for failing to report when both divisions of RT differential flow instruments were placed in bypass, which rendered the instruments inoperable and resulted in a loss of the isolation function. This issue is also discussed in IR 2645140 (3D Classification with a Work Group Evaluation) and IR 2652522 (2B Classification with ACE). LS-AA-1003 requires that the responsible organization reviews the NRC issues and ensures the station response and corrective actions properly address the violation and the crosscutting aspect. The NRC issue is as follows: Introduction: The Inspectors identified a Severity Level IV NCV for failing to report an event or condition, that at the time of discovery could have prevented the fulfillment of a safety function, to the NRC within eight hours. Specifically, control room operators placed both divisions of RT differential flow instruments in bypass, which rendered the instruments inoperable and resulted in a loss of the isolation function. Description: On January 25, 2016, control room personnel placed the RT 'A' filter demineralizer in hold for backwash and pre-coat per Station Procedure CPS 3303.01, "Reactor Water Cleanup," Section 8.1.3, and Station Procedure CPS 3302.02, "Reactor Water Cleanup Filter Demineralizer 'A' Operating Procedure," Sections 8.2 and 8.5. While placing the RT 'A' filter demineralizer back into service per Station Procedure CPS 3302.02, Section 8.6, the control room received an RT differential flow alarm. The control room operators placed both divisions of RT differential flow instruments in bypass per Station Procedure CPS 3303.01, which rendered the instruments inoperable and resulted in a loss of the isolation function. The licensee entered TS 3.3.6.1, action D.1, which stated to place channel in trip in 24 hours and action E.1, which stated to restore RT isolation capability in 1 hour. The procedure section to place the RT 'A' filter demineralizer in service was completed and the control room operators placed both divisions of RT differential flow instruments in normal, performed a channel check, and exited TS 3.3.6.1, actions D.1 and E.1. The operations logs documented that the licensee reviewed NRC's guidance for reporting events, NUREG.1022, Section 3.2.7, "Event or Condition that Could Have Prevented Fulfillment of a Safety Function." The operators determined that the condition was not reportable to the NRC based on the statement that "reports are not required when systems are declared inoperable as part of a planned evolution for maintenance or surveillance testing when done in accordance with an approved procedure and the plant's TS (unless a condition is discovered that would have resulted in the system being declared inoperable)." After reviewing the logs on the following day the inspectors asked the control room operators why the activity was considered a planned evolution for maintenance and not considered routine operation of the RT system. The licensee did not provide information to support the activity was a maintenance activity, so the inspectors reviewed the requirements of NUREG.1022 and determined that the condition was reportable. The licensee documented the issue in their CAP as AR 02652522 and created an action to submit a licensee event report (LER). This inspectors' review focused on the reportability aspect of placing the RT differential flow switches in bypass. The inspectors have not reviewed the technical justification or analyses associated with putting the differential flow switches in bypass while the system is in operation, therefore, they have not determined whether this action is in compliance with regulatory requirements. The inspectors planned to review the technical justification and analyses following the receipt of the licensee's LER. Analysis: The inspectors determined that the failure to report an event or condition, that at the time of discovery could have prevented the fulfillment of a safety function, to the NRC within eight hours was a performance deficiency. Specifically, the licensee failed to notify the NRC after placing both divisions of RT differential flow instrumentation in bypass, which rendered the instruments inoperable and resulted in a loss of the isolation function. The inspectors reviewed this issue in accordance with IMC 0612 and the Enforcement Manual. Violations are dispositioned using the traditional enforcement process because they are considered to be violations that potentially impede or impact the regulatory process. The inspectors reviewed Section 6.9.d.9 of the NRC Enforcement Policy and determined this violation was a Severity Level IV violation because the licensee's failure to make the report did not cause the NRC to reconsider a regulatory position or undertake substantial further inquiry. No cross-cutting aspect was assigned because cross-cutting aspects are not assigned to traditional enforcement-only violations. Enforcement: The licensee report within eight hours any event or condition, that at the time of discovery, could have prevented the fulfillment of a safety function needed to mitigate the consequence of an accident. Contrary to the above, on January 25, 2016, the licensee failed to report, within eight hours, a condition that, at the time of discovery, could have prevented the fulfillment of a safety function needed to mitigate the consequence of an accident. Specifically, control room personnel placed both divisions of RT differential flow instrumentation in bypass, which rendered the instruments inoperable and resulted in a loss of the isolation function needed to mitigate the consequences of an accident. In accordance with the Enforcement Policy, the violation was classified as a Severity Level IV violation. Because this violation was of very low safety significance, was not repetitive or willful, and was entered into the licensee's CAP as AR 02652522, it is being treated as an NCV, consistent with Section 2.3.2 of the NRC Enforcement Policy (NCV 05000461/2016001.03: Failure to Report a Condition that Could Have Prevented Fulfillment of a Safety Function). Corrective actions included creating an action to submit an LER.

DW (primary containment) venting, in Modes 1-3, will mask the DW pressure response from an RCS leak/LOCA; potentially challenging design basis assumptions and safety systems which actuate at 2.5 psig DW Pressure.

The compressor #1 and compressor #2 for the 0VV030C (TSC Condensing Unit) are repeatedly tripping during hot weather. Attempts to restart via BwOP VV-33/34 were only temporarily successful. The BwAR suggests calling upon EMD for troubleshooting if the compressors cant be maintained running. OPS trouble shooting is still ongoing, but this IR is being generated ASAP because this is a potentially 1-HR reportable item.

On 7-18-16 at 14:50 hrs the weekly ERO notification test for Quad Cities station failed. At 16:00 hrs the site EPM performed an announced ERO Call-in Drill to determine the extent of the Everbridge failure. At that point it was determined that the entire Everbridge ERO Notification System was not working. The ERO was notified at 15:42 hrs that a possible issue with notification was occurring and to stand-by for additional testing. After working with the Mid-Atlantic Fleet owners of the Everbridge system the system was restored. A follow-up Call-In Drill test was performed satisfactory at 19:34 hrs.

Informed by EP that at time 1500, there was a problem with the Everbridge notification system and there is not enough evidence to suggest that Everbridge would have worked per design to comply with EP/ERO requirements, and they agree this is reportable. An 8 hour notification is required by time 2300CDT. Corporate has initiated a prompt investigation. @1957 as requested by EP, initiated an ERO call in drill per EP-AA-112-100-F-06 "ERO NOTIFICATION OR AUGMENTATION". At 2030 notified by EP that the call in drill was successful. @2030 Dresden notification for per OP-AA-106-101 for the ENS reporting are complete @2107 ENS 52098 notification complete. "This 8-hour non-emergency report is being made based upon requirements which states, The licensee shall notify the NRC as soon as practical and in all cases within eight hours of the occurrence of any event that results in a major loss of emergency assessment capability, offsite response capability, or offsite communications capability (e.g., significant portion of control room indication, Emergency Notification System, or offsite notification system). Loss of EP Offsite Communications Capability Testing of the Everbridge ERO Notification system identified the system cannot notify all ERO individuals. This constitutes a loss of Offsite Communications Capability. Compensatory measures (ERO Phone lists) were put in place. The Everbridge system capability loss for Dresden Station was identified at 15:00 CDT on July 18, 2016, due to an undetermined loss of system communications. Emergency Response Data System (ERDS) capability was not lost. This event is reportable as a major loss of communication capability. On July 18, 2016 at 19:57 CDT an Everbridge ERO call in drill was initiated and verified successful at 20:30 The NRC Resident Inspector has been notified

During testing it was found that the Everbridge ERO notification system may not have been able to notify corporate ERO members within the required ten minutes from system initiation. The system issue did not affect the capability to notify Byron site ERO members - only corporate EOF ERO members. The Everbridge vendor was notified and has since fixed the problem. The corporate ERO notification system was successfully test with the system activating normally. Additionally, Byron EP staff successfully conducted a test of this system for site ERO members - the system responded as expected. This did not affect the Emergency Response Data System (ERDS).

Received notification that other Exelon Mid-West sites have experienced issues with Everbridge completing the required emergency response team notification in a timely manner. Received notification that the Everbridge system would not have notified the corporate EOF if the system had been activated for an event at LaSalle Station. This issue would have impaired the ability to implement the functions of the emergency plan if an emergency would have occurred.

Notified NRC via ENS notification 52107 of planned maintenance on the TSC ventilation system. The TSC outage is reportable per SAF 1.10. TSC ventilation work is scheduled to be completed within 14 hours.

At 0934 the MCR received a call from an engineer in the field asking why the 1B DOST room's watertight door (0DSSD192) was open. There was no planned reason for the door to be open. The T1 Operator was dispatched to investigate. The operator found nothing unusual except for the open door. The T1 Operator closed the door. Security determined that the last entry to the security door protected by the watertight door was at 0628 on 8/2/16. This leaves a three hour and six minute period of time where the watertight door was potentially open and unattended. The alarm that sounds when the door is open was not working. That issue is documented in a subsequent IR.
Received alarm 229 C-4, 'B' CAC/CAD ANALYZER TROUBLE. Performed actions of ARC 20C284 C-4. EO reports sample pump breaker is not tripped.

This step checks the pilot cell voltage. The reading for Pilot Cell (#4) was 2.09 VDC, acceptance criteria is greater than or equal to 2.13 VDC. This step is a black box step.

Through wall steam leak found on 1-2301-55, *U1 HPCI STM LINE DRN LINE STM TRAP OUTLET VLV. Leak is on the top of the body, down stream side near the corner where bonnet transitions to piping connection. No visible plume, but is audible near the valve. A screwdriver tip was placed in front of the leak to locate the exact location. Steam condensed on the screwdriver, indicating the leak. The leak cannot be felt from about 3 feet away.

During the performance of RT-O-57A-745-2 Balance of Plant and Miscellaneous Battery Monthly Check, Step 6.1.6 on Data Sheet 16 "10D040 Unit 1 54VDC Omni-Telephone Battery" was unsat. This step checks the pilot cell voltage. The reading for Pilot Cell (#4) was 2.08 VDC, acceptance criteria is greater than or equal to 2.13 VDC. This step is a black box step. This is a follow up issue on IR# 02724006 (A2062105). The retest as requested was unsat and this should be routed back to engineering for recommendations.

On January 2, 2017 at 12:52 LaSalle County 911 inadvertently activated 2 Exelon sirens (LS07 and LS10) located in Seneca. LaSalle County 911 stated that an individual was performing service work on the radio console and may have accidentally activated the 2 Seneca Sirens.

THIS IR ACTION IS BEING GENERATED TO TRACK THE LAB TESTING FOR THE CHARCOAL SAMPLE REMOVED PER SYSTEM ENGINEERING PROCEDURE N1-TTP-046 AND WORK ORDER C93292338. THE CHARCOAL SAMPLE REMOVED DURING PERFORMANCE OF N1-TTP-046 STEP 7.2.6 REQUIRES AN IR TO BE INITIATED TO INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING: COMPID OF SAMPLED FILTER: 212-39 DATE OF SAMPLE REMOVAL: 1/3/17 REQUIRED COMPLETION DATE: 2/3/17 (SAMPLE DATE + 31 DAYS) IR ASSIGNED TO SYSTEM MANAGER TALON SPROUSE

This IR documents a historical condition that was identified during time line development for the reportable condition associated with IR 3955705 (HV-011-015A ESW Return FSSD issue). During the time period of January 17, 2016 and April 8, 2016 a blank flange was installed by ECR LG14-00193 at flow element FE-011-011B to allow installation of a new manual valve 011-0125B in series with valve HV-011-011B. With this blank flange installed, only one of the two credited "B" loop ESW return paths to the spray pond was available. The blank flange was removed during 1R16 after completion of scheduled RHRSW piping maintenance and installation of new manual valve 011-0125B. This is analogous to the condition identified in IR 3955705 which also had one of the two credited ESW loop return paths to the spray pond unavailable. The existing fire safe shutdown analysis (FSSD) credits both return paths in order to mitigate certain single spurious fire induced valve operations. IR3955705 identified a non-compliant FSSD condition with the "A" ESW return loop. This IR is identifying a historical non-compliant FSSD unanalyzed condition on the "B" ESW return loop. FSSD Impact: A contract was issued to have the Limerick FSSD SME review this historical condition. This review identified that the three fire area analyses were impacted by the blank flange installed by ECR LG14-00193. The three impacted fire areas are 16, 45E and 82. The historical impact of ECR LG14-00193 to these fire areas is as follows: Fire Area 016 . Some credited B/D train safe shutdown equipment would no longer be available, however sufficient redundant equipment remained available to meet the FSSD regulatory requirements. No additional manual actions required to compensate for the additional failures. Fire Area 082 . Some credited B/D train safe shutdown equipment would no longer be available, however sufficient redundant equipment remained available to meet the FSSD regulatory requirements. No additional manual actions required to compensate for the additional failures. Fire Area 045E . NO credited safe shutdown method remain available. This review identified that fire area 45E (Eastern Half of Limerick Unit 1 Reactor Enclosure Elevation 253'-0") was not in compliance with the existing FSSD analysis while the blank flange was installed. The review results for the impacted areas were also confirmed by Site Engineering personnel. ECR LG14-00193 and its associated screening did not identify and address that fire area 45E would not be compliant with the existing analysis documented in UFSAR chapter 9A (FPER). The FSSD analysis credits both return flow paths so that Emergency Service Water can be returned to the spray pond while remaining tolerant to certain spurious valve operations. For fire area 45E, with only one of the two return flow paths available, a single spurious fire induced closure of valve HV-011-015B can result in deadheading of a B loop ESW pump. This will cause a loss of cooling water to the credited B RHR pump compartment room coolers and the credited RHR pump motor oil cooler. Fire Area 45E credits Fire Safe Shutdown Method C. If the credited B RHR pump fails due to loss of compartment cooling and motor oil cooling caused by the single spurious fire induced closure of HV-011-015B, it will prevent "B" LPCI injection which is credited for RPV inventory control at approximately 20 to 25 minutes into the post fire event. This could result in the only credited safe shutdown method (C) being unavailable. The plant would not have been able to achieve safe shutdown, because the single credited safe shutdown method could have been lost. This historical issue may be reportable. It can result in a noncompliance with current fire safe shutdown analysis documented in the fire protection evaluation report and fire protection program which is the current Limerick licensing basis (CLB). The current Limerick licensing basis assumes a single spurious actuation of safe shutdown components during any single deterministic fire event for plant areas as documented in Limerick UFSAR FPER section 9A. 5. The identified historical issue results in a single spurious actuation that can impact the ability to safely shutdown. With the loss of the single credited safe shutdown method during the postulated area wide fire in fire area 45E, the plant could not have been able to achieve safe shutdown. This condition is therefore unanalyzed.

While performing WO# 1940764-01 for an operability surveillance for the TSC AFU's IAW DOP 5750-05, it was discovered that the 2/3-5772-122 TSC HVAC AFU OUTSIDE AIR DAMPER is not re-positioning for achieve required flow. The acceptance criteria for AFU flow is between 900-1100 cfm. Flow was recorded at 670 cfm. Per the system engineer, the 2/3-5772-122 provides 250 cfm of outside air flow, but with it closed there is 0 flow.

Concurrent with tagout U1X-33B-0131 application, a turbine trip signal and HPCI initiation occurred. This tagout was the first in a series of tagouts to establish 345kV backfeed. Major equipment removed from service: Generator Disconnect Switch (SW-18) Station Power Board supply breakers (PB-11 and 12 normal supply breakers) Generator Excitation (AVR) 345kV Metering circuits Generator leads cooling fans Turbine Trip Handle

During realignment of SFP purification from 21 RWT to the SFP inventory was inadvertently transferred from 21 RWT to the SFP. This caused a low level alarm in 21RWT, with minimum wide range level recorded on the plant computer of 38.2', and a high level alarm in the spent fuel pool with a final level of approximately 67'4". Following identification of issue 12 SFP cooling pump was secured which stopped the transfer, and 21 RWT level was restored to a level of 38.86' approximately 45 minutes later.

An issue was identified at Oyster Creek related to EAL E-HU1, Damage to a loaded cask CONFINEMENT BOUNDARY documented under IR 4003001. Byron Station reviewed ISFSI cask documentation certificates of compliance for all dry casks loaded at the site. It was identified that all dry cask containers are identical however they were loaded under different certificates of compliance. The variations between these certificates included different limit values for the measured dose rates on a loaded OVERPACK. The first six casks at Byron were loaded under certificate of compliance No. 1014 revision 3 which contained limit values for the measure dose rates on a loaded OVERPACK of > 20 mr/hr (gamma + neutron) on the top of the spent fuel cask or > 110mr/hr (gamma + neutron) on the side of the spent fuel cask, excluding inlet and outlet ducts. Whereas the remainder of the casks were loaded under certificate of compliance No. 1014 revision 7 and 9 revision 1. These certificates contained limit values for the measure dose rates on a loaded OVERPACK of > 30 mr/hr (gamma + neutron) on the top of the spent fuel cask or > 300 mr/hr (gamma + neutron) on the side of the spent fuel cask, excluding inlet and outlet ducts. It was identified that the current EAL action level in EP-AA-1002 Addendum 3, Emergency Action Levels for Byron Station, Revision 1 UE E-HU1 is based on the certificate of compliance No. 1014 Revision 9 revision 1. (limit values for the measure dose rates on a loaded OVERPACK of > 30 mr/hr (gamma + neutron) on the top of the spent fuel cask or > 300 mr/hr (gamma + neutron) on the side of the spent fuel cask, excluding inlet and outlet ducts) NEI 99-01 requires that the UE EAL is 2 times the TS initial loading limit. Resulting in the EAL threshold values of > 60mr/hr (gamma + neutron) on the top of the spent fuel cask or > 600mr/hr (gamma + neutron) on the side of the spent fuel cask, excluding inlet and outlet ducts. This difference was not recognized when the EALs were revised in February 2016 to revision 6 of NEI 99-01. Reportability was reviewed using EP-AA-120-1006, EP Reportability . Loss of Emergency Preparedness Capabilities and discussed with corporate EP and found this condition is not reportable as this is an EAL threshold value problem and not a loss of emergency assessment capability from a loss of a structure or equipment, including indications, display systems and annunciators that prevent the evaluation of all EALs for an emergency Initiating Condition (IC).

An issue was identified at Oyster Creek related to EAL E-HU1, Damage to a loaded cask CONFINEMENT BOUNDARY documented under IR 4003001. PB Station Engineering reviewed ISFSI cask documentation certificates of compliance for all dry casks loaded at the site. It was identified that all dry cask containers are essentially the same; however, they were loaded under two different certificates of compliance amendments. The variations between these amendments included different limit values for the measured dose rates. There exists three casks (45, 46 and 47) at PB loaded under Certificate of Compliance (C of C) 1027 / Technical Specification Amendment 0; with the remaining 77 casks have been analyzed to be in compliance with C of C 1027 / Technical Specification Amendment 1. It was identified that the current EAL threshold values listed in EP-AA-1007 Addendum 3, Emergency Action Levels for Peach Bottom Station, Revision 4, UE EAL E-HU1 are based on the certificate of compliance 1027 Technical Specification Amendment 1 TS 5.2.3.3 limits assuming design basis fuel is loaded in the casks. These values are different that the certificate of compliance 1027, Technical Specification Amendment 0 values of measured dose rates. Additionally, most loaded TN casks assume cask specific lower limiting dose rates as in accordance with TS 5.2.3.2, not TS 5.2.3.3. For amendment 0 casks (45, 46, 47), the TS dose limits are about 2/3 of what they are for amendment 1 casks (of which the EAL is based on). Also, the TS 5.2.3.2 cask specific dose rates (of which is credited in the PBAPS analysis) are also substantially lower limits than the TS 5.2.3.3 dose rates for design basis fuel (which PBAPS does not credit for all loaded casks). It appears that by calculating the PBAPS EAL as twice the values of the TS 5.2.3.3, this would make the EAL threshold artificially high. This difference in certificate of compliances was not recognized when the EALs were revised in December 2015 to revision 6 of NEI 99-01. Reportability specific to EP was reviewed using EP-AA-120-1006, EP Reportability. Loss of Emergency Preparedness Capabilities and discussed with corporate EP and found this condition is not reportable as this is an EAL threshold value problem and not a loss of emergency assessment capability from a loss of a structure or equipment, including indications, display systems and annunciators that prevent the evaluation of all EALs for an emergency Initiating Condition (IC). Actions are: -Engineering to perform the required reviews to determine the accurate EAL threshold values for the two certificate of compliance casks; -EP to process these changes into EP-AA-1007, Appendix 3 for Initiating Condition E-HU1.

An issue was identified at Oyster Creek related to EAL E-HU1, "Damage to a loaded cask CONFINEMENT BOUNDARY," as documented under IR 4003001, where Oyster had two types of DCS canisters on the pad and the EAL was based on the limits for only one type. As a result, Quad Cities reviewed ISFSI dry cask storage (DCS) Certificate of Compliance (CoC) documentation for all DCS containers placed on the ISFSI pad. It was identified that all DCS containers are of the same type; however, they were loaded under different CoC Amendments/Revisions. The variations between these CoC Amendments/Revisions includes different maximum dose rate limits for the measured dose rates on a loaded OVERPACK as specified in DCS Technical Specification (TS) 5.7.4. The first 37 casks at Quad Cities were loaded under CoC No. 1014 Amendment Nos. 2 and 3. The associated DCS TS 5.7.4 for these Amendments states that the measured dose rates on a loaded OVERPACK shall not exceed the following values: a. 20 mr/hr (gamma + neutron) on the top of the OVERPACK b. 110 mr/hr (gamma + neutron) on the side of the OVERPACK, excluding inlet and outlet ducts. The last 11 casks loaded on the ISFSI at Quad Cities meet the requirements of CoC No. 1014 Amendment No. 8, Revision No. 1. The associated DCS TS 3.7.4 states that the measured dose rates on a loaded OVERPACK shall not exceed the following values: a. 30 mr/hr (gamma + neutron) on the top of the OVERPACK b. 300 mr/hr (gamma + neutron) on the side of the OVERPACK, excluding inlet and outlet ducts. It was identified that the current EAL action level in EP-AA-1006 Addendum 3, "Emergency Action Levels for Quad Cities Station," Revision 3, for UE EAL E-HU1 is based on the limits from CoC No. 1014 Amendment No. 2 and 3, i.e., 40 mr/hr (gamma + neutron) on the top of the OVERPACK and 220 mr/hr (gamma + neutron) on the side of the OVERPACK, excluding inlet and outlet ducts. The current EALs are based on NEI 99-01, "Development of Emergency Action Levels for Non-Passive Reactors," Revision 6. As described in NEI 99-01, Revision 6, the basis for this UE EAL threshold is "2 times the site-specific cask specific technical specification allowable radiation level." Furthermore, NEI 99-01, Revision 6 states that emphasis for this classification is the degradation in the level of safety of the spent fuel cask and not the magnitude of the associated dose or dose rate. At issue is the magnitude of the dose rate at the cask at which the site will declare an unusual event; there are no potential escalation paths for this EAL. When a HI-STORM is loaded onto the ISFSI pad, the TS limit is verified per RP-QC-304. While the procedure was updated to reflect the higher TS limits as discussed above, this procedure also verifies the dose rate is lower than an administrative limit (25 mr/hr for the side and 8.5 mr/hr for the top) that ensures that the fuel loaded onto the ISFSI had a baseline dose rate that was significantly less than the dose rate limits of the amendments used to establish the EAL. The DCS work orders for the eleven casks loaded to Amendment 8 Revision 1 (WPs 01614866 and 01805377) were reviewed and the maximum dose rates measured per RP-QC-304 were 1.7 mr/hr on the side and 1.3 mr/hr on the top. The fact that the casks loaded on the ISFSI pad at Quad Cities Station comply with different CoC Amendments/Revisions and have different DCS TS 5.7.4 limits was not recognized when the EALs were revised to meet NEI 99-01, Revision 6. The need to specify different EAL thresholds associated with the different CoC Amendments/Revisions is being questioned. Since the baseline dose rates of the casks are significantly lower than the dose rates used to establish the current EAL at Quad Cities, the use of the current EAL is appropriate while this issue is investigated further.

During the performance of RT-O-57M-790-2 OMNI Battery Quarterly Inspection, the voltage reading for 10D040 cell #14 was 2.06VDC. Acceptance criteria per step 6.1.13 is greater than or equal to 2.13 VDC. This step is a black box step.

A non radioactive sealand from outside the protected area was shipped to local scrap yard. Upon arrival the sealand alarmed the radiation monitor at the scrap yard. The trucking company brought the sealand back to site.

During scheduled work under WO C93221528, Network Intrusion Detection Phase II, an unexpected network error occurred causing brief loss of plant network connectivity. This impacted U2 PI data, DRMS, and TARS. Unit 1 Control Room noticed a computer trouble alarm which cleared immediately.

Low DP alarm came in for the TSC HVAC. After investigating the issue it was determined that the belts for the moter/fan assembly had broken due to extended use. Belts were inspected to insure no fire was present and to determine cause of failure.

A plant maintenance technician identified an unattended duffel bag in a site parking lot located within the Owner Controlled Area at 0149 on August 23, 2017. Plant Security personnel investigated and subsequently contacted the local law enforcement agency (Oswego County Sheriff's Department) for assistance at 0155. Local Law Enforcement Agencies are actively investigating the unattended bag. The NRC resident inspector (Ken Kolaczyk) and the Nuclear Duty Officer (Randy Dus) have been notified. This condition was screened for a Prompt Investigation and did not meet the criterion per OP-AA-106-101-1001.

R-1 radiation reading for the control room went into high warning at 1.79mrem/hr and then returned to approximately .1mrem/hr. After a review of PPCS plot for R-1 it was determined that it started spiking up in reading on 08/31/17 at approximately 2216.

During the planned Reactor Building loading during pre-outage activities, the equipment hatch inner door was able to be cycled open while the outer door was not fully closed. The door interlock between the inner and outer doors failed allowing the inner door to be open without the exterior door being fully closed. The total time of both doors being open simultaneously was less than 15 seconds based on report from technicians in the field.

EO ID - During second set of Red Floor checks, the Overvoltage target and reset light on MCC 18/19-5 were found lit. Target is only halfway open. Red light above target is lit. Overfrequency relay on 18/19-5 already has a known issue, reference IR 4025916

This IR identifies a non-conforming condition with the both Emergency Diesel Generator (EDG) fuel oil day tank vents with respect to tornado missile protection. Inadequate function of vents can result in a loss of fuel oil supply to EDGs. Since the fuel oil supply is an integral component of the EDG's and is not protected against tornado missiles, the design does not meet the licensing basis and a non-conforming condition exists. NRC Enforcement Guidance Memorandum EGM 15-002, Revision 1, provides for application of NRC enforcement discretion which allow the diesel generators EG-Y-1A and EG-Y-1B to be returned to an operable status based on the application of Comp Measures which are intended to reduce the likelihood that the tornado event would result in a failure of the EDGs. Application of the guidance in EGM 15-002, Revision 1, and, NRC DSS-ISG-2016-01 Revision 1 Appendix A, describes acceptable initial and comprehensive compensatory measures necessary to ensure that the identified nonconforming condition in this issue report can be treated by the NRC with enforcement discretion. Per guidance in NRC DSS-ISG-2016-01 Revision 1, "The measures listed below should be verified as current and readily deployable within a very short timeframe." The initial IR (#4081290) and the ENS notification (#53106), with respect to tornado missile protection, are issued on December 6th, 2017.

This IR identifies a non-conforming condition with Borated water supply for safe shutdown after a design basis tornado. Neither of the emergency sources, currently described in emergency procedures, the Borated Water Storage Tank (DH-T-1) or the Boric Acid Mix Tank (CA-T-1) are protected against the tornado-generated missiles. A borated water supply is required to maintain sufficient RCS inventory to support RCS heat removal and raise RCS boron concentration to maintain the reactor shutdown after Xenon decays. The borated water supply function does not meet the licensing basis and a non-conforming condition exists. NRC Enforcement Guidance Memorandum EGM 15-002, Revision 1, provides for application of NRC enforcement discretion which allow the components associated with Borated Water Supply function to be returned to an operable status based on the application of Comp Measures which are intended to reduce the likelihood that the tornado event would result in a failure of the borated water supply. Application of the guidance in EGM 15-002, Revision 1, and, NRC DSS-ISG-2016-01 Revision 1 Appendix A, describes acceptable initial and comprehensive compensatory measures necessary to ensure that the identified nonconforming condition in this issue report can be treated by the NRC with enforcement discretion. Per guidance in NRC DSS-ISG-2016-01 Revision 1, "The measures listed below should be verified as current and readily deployable within a very short timeframe." The initial IR (#4081290) and the ENS notification (#53106), with respect to tornado missile protection, are issued on December 6th, 2017.

During a review of Ginna EAL's to identify single point vulnerabilities as an Extent of Condition for AR 04074137, it was identified that High Lake Level used for classification of HU1.5 & HA1.5 presents a single point vulnerability. Per EP-AA-1012 Addendum 3, "High lake level may be determined using markers attached to a metal pole mounted on the discharge canal bridge upstream of the submarine net. The high level markers are at lake levels of 252 ft and 253 ft". Ginna has one pole with one 252 foot marker for the UE level indication and one 253 foot marker for the Alert level indication. If either of these markers are lost, we would not have indication of its associated EAL threshold. Also if the entire pole was lost, damaged, or not visible for any reason, we would not have indications available to classify the event. This would require an 8 hour NRC report due to a Loss of Emergency Preparedness Capabilities caused by a Loss of Emergency Classification Capability.

During performance of QCOS 2300-30 on U-2, when a HPCI full initiation signal was inserted, the HPCI Auxiliary Oil Pump failed to start. Due to the failure of the HPCI Auxiliary Oil Pump to start, subsequent actions that occur following Auxiliary Oil Pump start failed to occur as well. The HPCI Auxiliary Oil Pump was started per QCOS 2300-17 and operated as expected. Further troubleshooting revealed that PS 2-2341-4 contacts 3-4 are open with no HPCI Oil Pumps running and the oil system depressurized. Follow up troubleshooting is recommended to verify the failure. A continuity check was performed from 902-39 EE-78 and AA-45 and revealed open contacts from the pressure switch. The pressure switch contacts should be closed which in turn energizes relay 2-2330-166 and automatically starts the HPCI Auxiliary Oil Pump. Reference 4E-2532. The logic test was suspended in the current lineup to allow further troubleshooting as necessary.

During a walkdown performed in the Drywell Basement, it was identified that box guide support 2305-G-102.2 has two (2) of four (4) broken welds in the attachment to the beam (Item 3 on detail drawing M-328G Sheet 21) with the other 2 welds being intact. This support is located in the drywell basement on line number 2-2305-10"-B which is the HPCI Steam Supply Line (Isometric: M-3118 Sheet 1). This is a ASME Class 1 support. Support 2305-G-102.2 is not part of the Q2R24 (2018) ISI Scope, but it is part of Q2R25 (2020) ISI Scope. There is no required ISI scope expansion as this was not identified during an scheduled ISI exam. This support has been previously examined per ASME Section XI in Q2R20 (2010) and Q2R16 (2002) with no indications. Reviewed drawings and discussed extent of condition (EOC) with NDE personnel who identified issue, and confirmed adjacent support was already walkdown with no issues identified. Contacted Design Engineering and it was agreed that the welds of this support needs to be fixed.

Formal review of the following for applicability: Power ReactorEvent Number: 53388 Facility: CALLAWAY Region: 4 State: MO Unit: 1 RX Type: 1 W-4-LP NRC Notified By: JEREMY MORTON HQ OPS Officer: DAN LIVERMORE Notification Date: 05/07/2018 Notification Time: 16:31 ET Event Date: 05/07/2018 Event Time: 13:35 CDT Last Update Date: 05/07/2018 Emergency Class: NON EMERGENCY Person (Organization): MARK HAIRE (R4DO) UnitSCRAM CodeRX CRITInitial PWRInitial RX ModeCurrent PWRCurrent RX Mode 1NY100Power Operation100Power Operation DISCOVERY OF A CONDITION THAT COULD HAVE PREVENTED FULFILLMENT OF A SAFETY FUNCTION "On May 7, 2018, during an engineering review of mission time requirements for Technical Specification related equipment, a deficiency was discovered regarding the Emergency Operating Procedure (EOP) guidance for natural circulation cooldown with a stagnant loop. This condition could be the result of a postulated Main Steam Line Break with a loss of offsite power. "During a natural circulation cooldown with a faulted steam generator, flow in the stagnant reactor coolant system (RCS) loop associated with the isolated faulted steam generator (SG) could stagnate and result in elevated temperatures in that loop. This becomes an issue when RCS depressurization to residual heat removal system (RHR) entry conditions is attempted. The liquid in the stagnant loop will flash to steam and prevent RCS depressurization. In this condition, the time required to complete the cooldown would be sufficiently long that the nitrogen accumulators associated with Callaway's atmospheric steam dumps and turbine driven auxiliary feedwater pump flow control valves would be exhausted. The atmospheric steam dumps and turbine driven auxiliary feedwater pump would not be capable of performing their specified safety functions of cooling the plant to entry conditions for RHR operation. This issue has been analyzed by Westinghouse in WCAP-16632-P. This WCAP determined that to prevent loop stagnation, the RCS cooldown rate in these conditions should be limited to a rate dependent on the temperature differential present in the active loops. "The WCAP analysis was used to support a revision to the generic Emergency Response Guideline (ERG) for ES-0.2 "Natural Circulation Cooldown." Figure 1 in ES-0.2 provides a curve of the maximum allowable cooldown rate as a function of active loop temperature differential which is directly proportional to the level of core decay heat. At the time of discovery of this condition, Callaway's EOP structure did not ensure that the ES-0.2 guidance would be implemented for a natural circulation cooldown with a stagnant loop. "Callaway has issued interim guidance to the on-shift personnel regarding this concern and is in the process of revising the applicable EOPs. "This condition is reportable for any event or condition that at the time of discovery could have prevented the fulfillment of the safety function of structures or systems that are needed to (A) Shutdown the reactor and maintain it in a safe shutdown condition, (B) Remove residual heat, or (D) mitigate the consequences of an accident."

This IR identifies a non-conforming condition with the Unit 1 Saltwater system header and associated piping for both subsystems located in the Intake Structure with respect to tornado missile protection. The Saltwater system header and some piping is vulnerable to a tornado missile that enters the Intake Structure through the watertight door, IS-2. The saltwater system provides a heat sink for the removal of process and operating heat from safety-related components during a transient or design basis accident. Since the saltwater system header and associated piping are not protected against a tornado missile entering through watertight door IS-2, the design does not meet the licensing basis and a non-conforming condition exists. NRC Enforcement Guidance Memorandum EGM 15-002, Revision 1, provides for application of NRC enforcement discretion which allow Unit 1 Saltwater System to be returned to an operable status based on the application of compensatory measures which are intended to reduce the likelihood that the tornado event would result in a failure of the Saltwater system. Application of the guidance in EGM 15-002, Revision 1, and NRC DSS-ISG-2016-01 Revision 1 Appendix A, describes acceptable initial and comprehensive compensatory measures necessary to ensure that the identified nonconforming condition in this issue report can be treated by the NRC with enforcement discretion. Per guidance in NRC DSS-ISG-2016-01 Revision 1, "The measures listed below should be verified as current and readily deployable within a very short timeframe." The resident inspector has been informed of this issue and of the intent to utilize enforcement discretion in accordance with EGM 15-002 (Rev 1).

The Saltwater system header and some piping is vulnerable to a tornado missile that enters the Intake Structure through the watertight door, IS-2. The saltwater system provides a heat sink for the removal of process and operating heat from safety-related components during a transient or design basis accident. Since the saltwater system header and associated piping are not protected against a tornado missile entering through watertight door IS-2, the design does not meet the licensing basis and a non-conforming condition exists.
